summary: The circumstances surrounding the death of crime novelist Harlan Thrombey are mysterious, but there's one thing that renowned Detective Benoit Blanc knows for sure -- everyone in the wildly dysfunctional Thrombey family is a suspect. Now, Blanc must sift through a web of lies and red herrings to uncover the truth.

reviews.content: Great cast!  It appears they have good chemistry.  Daniel Craig, Anna de Armas, Chris Evans, Don Johnson, Christopher Plummer, and etc.  It is a MUST SEE!

It's a mystery, a real mystery.  The first true mystery seen in a long time.  With suspects and clues and things are not what they appear.  With colorful suspects and a eccentric investigator.  I believe Agatha Christie would be a fan if she was alive today to see it.  A true modern murder mystery masterpiece.

Knives Out - How to do a Plot Twist

I have never seen a better example of subverting expectations than in Rian Johnson's Knives Out. If you want to shock your audience and do it right rather than some cheap trick, then there is no better case study than this film. There are rarely other films like this that perform a plot twist so effortlessly.
First of all, the plot twist we're talking about is Hugh Ransom Drysdale (played by the evil sweater wearing Chris Evans) being revealed as the true killer instead of Marta (played by Ana De Armas) which is believed to be the one almost throughout the entirety of the film.

The reason why Knives Out's plot twist works so well is because the film flips genres after a third of the way through. The entire first act is about it being a whodunit mystery; but, at the end of the first act, it exactly tells us what happened and who did it (in this case, Marta) and seemingly answers all our questions. All of a sudden, with the flip of a coin, it's no longer a whodunit; it's how the hell is Marta going to get away with it? And what I love so much about this genre flip is because it takes the story forward in an entire new direction. This flip weaponizes the tropes of the murder mystery genre and they themselves are the antagonists. Now, at the end of every murder mystery, the detective always finds out who is the real killer, it's a trope and every murder mystery film has it. The detective gathers every suspect, has a monologue about the series of events and finally points out the real murderer. So now, we're even more interested as to how will Benoit Blanc (played beautifully by the Scottish Daniel Craig) will catch Marta.

Another reason as to why the twist works so well is because it makes perfect logical sense with the story and fits each and everyone's character. The twist lands so well in that sweet spot where it's damn near impossible to figure it out beforehand but extremely obvious in hindsight. This is done beautifully due to the order in which information is fed to us. One example is the dogs barking clue where it becomes obvious who is the killer but we've reached a point in the film that we don't care about it and simply ignore it.

The last reason why I love this film so much is because we get everything the film promised itself to be. We get a murder mystery plot resolved (which was thought to be dead at the end of the first act) along with another plot of genre flip which collapse with each other in a beautiful cathartic climax.

There is not better way to say this. Rian Johnson, You're The Man!

This is the best who-done-it I have ever seen. It allows the viewer to try to solve the mystery as it is being watched with twists and turns that actually make sense. The entire cast is great and the characters feel real. A must-watch.

Its 2-hour runtime flies in as the viewer is assaulted with twists, turns, and the unbelievable talent of all actors involved. Daniel Craig stands out as Southern PI Benoit Blanc and perfectly represents the eccentricity of the film but also the control, keeping it away from but never too far from becoming a caricature of itself.

An absolutely wonderful film that completely exceeded my expectations.

When renowned crime novelist Harlan Thrombey (Christopher Plummer) is found dead at his estate just after his 85th birthday, Detective Benoit Blanc (Daniel Craig) is mysteriously enlisted to investigate the mysterious circumstances. From Harlan's dysfunctional family to his devoted staff, Blanc sifts through a web of evidence alongside red herrings and self-serving lies to uncover the truth and in doing so, shows us the different points of views of the suspects. With all the hallmarks of the classic murder mystery, there are a number of twists and turns which make it a little on the long side.

Every twist and turn just gets you more enthralled in this story that they're telling, and the final reveal makes sense while catching you off guard. The plot for this film is great, but my one issue is the setting. It just feels very boring in this old manor, and the other settings seen in the film aren't any better. Overall, Knives Out is a great movie, and It's a very solid start to what hopefully becomes an amazing franchise.

Rian Johnson's "Knives Out" is an old-fashioned, smartly plotted and suspenseful murder mystery proving that people of color deserve a place in a genre where they are all-too-often denied opportunities to solve murder cases due toward their race. With his first whodunnit, Johnson revives interest in a bygone genre by celebrating minorities' lives without being wounded by razor-sharp knives. It's the filmmaker's first attempt to bring a bygone genre surging back to life using social commentary as sharp as the pointed edge of a knife, but he pulls it off expertly. Using stunning visuals, Johnson draws viewers into a private detective's expeditions to investigate the unfortunate murder of a patriarch belonging a wealthy estate. Evoking Robert Altman's "Gosford Park", Johnson expertly utilizes the confined mansion location to create tension amongst the suspects of a murder investigation whose motives are called into question. Like the wealthy socialites disturbed to discover their lives are in danger following murders in Gosford Park, the confined mansion showcases the bitter rivalries amongst the Thrombey family. Johnson showcases immense control over the production-design, editing and music, creating an unforgettable cinematic experience. Johnson's screenplay is superb, creating a compassionate depiction of a marginalized community through subverting the whodunnit genre's conventions. One appreciates fantastic performances. Daniel Craig delivers one of his greatest career performances as Benoit Blanc. With mesmerizing expressions, he captures the angst, intelligence and suspicions of a detective determined to solve a murder investigation involving a family experiencing dysfunction. Ana de Armas is amazing as a ferocious Latin-American housekeeper who takes a stand against privileged employers wrongfully accusing her of murder. Armas conveys the resilient humanity of a housemaid through her expressions rather than words. Finally, Chris Evans deserves appreciation. As a snobbish son that mocks his family, he brings comical relief to the movie. Although "Knives Out" is undeniably a gripping murder mystery, it isn't a film without flaws. It builds toward predictable conclusions that lack satisfying closure. One can easily guess the identity of the killer which takes the tensions out of this murder mystery. Nevertheless, fans of the murder mystery genre will definitely appreciate "Knives Out" and so will movie-goers seeking exhilarating entertainment. If Cinema is a political art-form with the power to bring about change that can be used by filmmakers to speak out on issues which they are passionate about without having bloody knives drawn out, hopefully it will provide modern-day immigrants facing a drought with a Clue how to go about fighting for their basic human rights in a worn-out country governed by racist politicians that have sowed a seed of doubt from which marginalized Latin-American communities have all-too-often been turned out.

There's a reason why I don't fancy detective stories - they're all using the same old formula: pre-story, crime, search, resolution. Knives Out is no exception to this; although I have to admit that to have us shown who the real murderer is before the movie even hit the middle mark was a bit refreshing, as well as the further unraveling story after that. All-star cast has made it possible for me to enjoy every single minute of this whodunit except for maybe Daniel Craig who was trying a bit too hard at times to imitate the southern accent and his overall performance was in a way just another Hercule Poirot imitation but a fine one to say the least. In short Knives Out is a no time-waster for sure; it's almost exclusively a bottled movie shot within one location, with great soundtrack, solid characters, some witty dialogues, a bit too theatrical and hyperbolized narrative but entertaining and fun to watch nonetheless.

I can't not mention Daniel Craig's ludicrously over the top accent in this film, who sounds like a deeply thoughtful 'sleuth of the south' type. He has a similar accent in the film 'Logan Lucky' if I remember right. 

There are some intriguing plot twists, as we start to see more in terms of what happened from different characters perspectives/points of view. I also was quite keen on the main setting - a large, stately type home, which means many scenes have nice furniture and things in the background. This is certainly not a film to take entirely seriously but its a fun, whodunnit type watch - one which is fairly engrossing and thus  I'd recommend it.

Knives Out's, perhaps, most beneficial and successful feature is the power of payoffs. Every single scene carries a purpose to the main plot: to set up a seemingly minor detail that will then play a role in the story, ergo pay off. Everything that we ever perceive here is relevant: whether that's Marta's genius-plot-device puking condition or Ransom not showing up to the funeral or even such a tiny thing as a fragment of Harlan's beginning monologue ("Playing life like a game without consequence, until you can't tell the difference between a stage prop and a real knife."). Such writing is satisfying to both critics and the audience and naturally comes off as very smart storytelling, which, needless to say, Knives Out is.

Knives Out - How to do a Plot Twist

I have never seen a better example of subverting expectations than in Rian Johnson's Knives Out. If you want to shock your audience and do it right rather than some cheap trick, then there is no better case study than this film. There are rarely other films like this that perform a plot twist so effortlessly.

First of all, the plot twist we're talking about is Hugh Ransom Drysdale (played by the evil sweater wearing Chris Evans) being revealed as the true killer instead of Marta (played by Ana De Armas) which is believed to be the one almost throughout the entirety of the film.

The reason why Knives Out's plot twist works so well is because the film flips genres after a third of the way through. The entire first act is about it being a whodunit mystery; but, at the end of the first act, it exactly tells us what happened and who did it (in this case, Marta) and seemingly answers all our questions. All of a sudden, with the flip of a coin, it's no longer a whodunit; it's how the hell is Marta going to get away with it? And what I love so much about this genre flip is because it takes the story forward in an entire new direction. This flip weaponizes the tropes of the murder mystery genre and they themselves are the antagonists. Now, at the end of every murder mystery, the detective always finds out who is the real killer, it's a trope and every murder mystery film has it. The detective gathers every suspect, has a monologue about the series of events and finally points out the real murderer. So now, we're even more interested as to how will Benoit Blanc (played beautifully by the Scottish Daniel Craig) will catch Marta.

Another reason as to why the twist works so well is because it makes perfect logical sense with the story and fits each and everyone's character. The twist lands so well in that sweet spot where it's damn near impossible to figure it out beforehand but extremely obvious in hindsight. This is done beautifully due to the order in which information is fed to us. One example is the dogs barking clue where it becomes obvious who is the killer but we've reached a point in the film that we don't care about it and simply ignore it.

The last reason why I love this film so much is because we get everything the film promised itself to be. We get a murder mystery plot resolved (which was thought to be dead at the end of the first act) along with another plot of genre flip which collapse with each other in a beautiful cathartic climax.
There is not better way to say this. Rian Johnson, You're The Man!

A hilarious and shockingly fresh new murder-mystery film, "Knives Out" stands as one of the best films of the 2000s, packing emotion, drama, and comedy all into a beautifully woven masterpiece of a film. The atmosphere and cinematography are all extremely pleasant to look at, and the entire film is incredibly clever while also not being too hard to follow either. The acting is never just good; everyone is great in their roles, each actor or actress giving their strongest performance. The humor is also done very intelligently, with the jokes being extremely subtly added into the script. Plot is great, and the pacing is likewise great. The entire story is beautifully told and keeps you guessing from the start to finish, throwing many red herrings at you along the way. Overall, an extremely intelligent murder-mystery movie that stands tall among many others.

It was very hard to say no to watching 'Knives Out' and it was one of my most anticipated films since it came out. It was due to being busy and personal problems that stopped me from seeing it sooner. A lot drew me in to watching it. Absolutely love murder mysteries and seeing a lot of comparisons to one of my favourite authors Agatha Christie and the starry cast were reasons enough for me to see it, as well as the great reviews.

Found myself really enjoying, if not quite loving, 'Knives Out'. Can understand why it may not be for all, if one doesn't like seeing and hearing the truth much earlier on than they would expect, and it is easy to see the ridiculing for Daniel Craig's Southern accent (which is admittedly atrocious). Can totally understand its appeal and why it was so positively received though, because to me it was a well made, well acted and cleverly written film that shows that director Rian Johnson does have a great film in him. While not perfect or one of the best films ever made (though was not expecting 'The Godfather' or 'Casablanca' etc), it is a long way from being a 1/10 film, putting it down there with most of the films riffed on MST3K, films from SyFy and the Asylum, 'Home Alone 4', 'NeverEnding Story 3', 'Titanic: The Animated Movie' and the Baby Geniuses films is insulting. As far as 2019 goes, it is towards being one of the better films of that year if not one of the very best.

'Knives Out' had potential to be even better than it was. If it didn't overdo or repeat too much the vomiting running gag and slowed the final solution down (a suitably complicated one that is explained a little too fast for my liking) it would have been a better film.

Wouldn't have said no to the truth (well some of it was) being revealed later than it was, though even when it was placed when it was it was still in the final solution not at all what things initially seemed. The film is a little overlong as well.

However, so much works here. 'Knives Out' looks great, full of atmospheric colour, beautiful locations (the interiors of the house are especially atmospheric), stylishly photographed and slickly edited. Nathan Johnson's score has menace and energy, without feeling overused or over-scored. Johnson directs expertly with a clear love for the genre being sent up.

It is a cleverly scripted film too, shining especially in the smart and affectionate 70s murder mystery throwbacks and deliciously salty one liners and insults from Ransom. The story never felt dull to me and even when things seemed obvious too early some ingenious unexpected twists are brought in. Can totally see how Johnson was so influenced by Christie's writing, evidenced from as early on as the terrific opening sequence and with Christopher Plummer's patriarch character (a type of character seen frequently in Christie's books). A fine example of how to bring freshness to a very familiar genre often visited, while the final solution is incredibly clever though demands full attention.

Moreover, the ensemble cast, one of the best from that year, clearly have a ball. There is some delicious deadpan but also some inspired but not overdone scenery-chewing. Accent aside, Craig does a great job breaking away from his Bond image and revels being comedic in a laconic way. Plummer (RIP) is perfectly cast and while his screen time is not large he makes the absolute most of it. Ana De Armas has one of the most difficult roles and shows no signs of being taxed. Jamie Lee Curtis, Toni Collette, Don Johnson and Michael Shannon all give it everything they've got. My favourite performance came from Evans, also breaking away from typecasting, he was never this witty or salty.

Overall, very, very good. 8/10

Knives Out is a 2019 American movie written and directed by Rian Johnson and produced by Johnson and Ram Bergman. With movie stars like Chris Evans or Jamie Curtis as the main characters. 
	The story begins with one of the characters, housekeeper Fran, finding a dead body of beloved and awfully rich Harlan Thrombey. As the investigation begins, we, for the first time, can see the delicate detective Benoit Blanc played by the one and only Daniel Craig.
	The death of Harlan is believed to be a suicide. Not only is the detective not sure about the death being a suicide, the detective is on lead to the true killer.
	The producer and director Rian Craig Johnson is an American film and television director, screenwriter and producer. His debut film "Brick" won the Special Jury Prize for Originality of Vision at the Sundance Film Festival. He has also directed The Brothers Bloom and Looper

Writer/director Rain Johnson recovers following his divisive Star Wars film (personally, I enjoyed his darker Star Wars vision) with a wonderfully smart and witty murder mystery. With a stellar cast that includes Chris Evans, Jamie Lee Curtis, Michael Shannon, Don Johnson, Toni Collette, Christopher Plummer, and Daniel Craig as Detective Benoit Blanc (the lead of a soon to be film series), it's hard to imagine this film not being great. The set up is standard Agatha Christie with rich patriarch Plummer found dead and all of the family angling for his fortune being suspect. Although the set-up is standard, Johnson subverts murder mystery conventions, with the cause of death revealed early in the film, but best of all it's the audience who has all the facts and Daniel Craig's detective left in the dark. I don't want to spoil the story, but MINOR SPOILER ALTERT, much of the film's suspense boils down to the fate of a sympathetic protagonist. Overall, if you love a crackling good mystery or wonderful ensemble casts, don't miss this film. BONUS FILM SUGGESTION! If you enjoyed "Knives Out" you should check out Rain Johnson's first film as writer/director, "Brick." It's another wildly fun murder mystery, though it's in the mold of Raymond Chandler with a high school Joseph Gordon-Levitt as a noirish teenage Phillip Marlow.

Audiences seem to be tired of repetitive movie plots, dreading remakes and familiar themes. We have seen aliens invading Earth, teenagers falling in love, and whodunit mysteries. What separates a film from being "another remake" is how a director takes a used idea and makes it fresh by adding their own spice. In return, one forgets previous judgement and becomes captivated to the point of claiming said-film a "masterpiece." This is exactly what Rian Johnson does in Knives Out.

From a stacked and well-acted cast to the well-wrttien screenplay to the interesting film editing, Knives Out is wild ride that goes everywhere in the most organized way, never once falling into plot-holes. It leaves its audience on the edge of their seat, constantly making us change our theories of how the film will end, in this case, who is Harlan Thrombey's killer.

A murder mystery that contains both an accidental and intentional murder. This is just one aspect in where the pure genius of the films lies.

I do have to add another place in the film where the pure genius lies and it is in a place where films do not execute well. Johnson sneakily adds political commentary on serious issues happening in our country during the former president's term. There is nothing exhausting in adding activism but at times, it comes off forced and unnecessary. A combination of the acting and screenplay in this scene did the complete opposite. Their political commentary also added more insight in each character's personality and therefore, their development.

The film is simply so good on its own it makes us nervous for the sequel and trilogy to come but, in Rian Johnson we trust.
Knives Out is a must watch. Great story with a lot of twists that are completely unexpected, paired with a phenomenal cast, truly gives you a great movie.

Rhian Johnson's follow up to his Star Wars effort was another left field turn from him, a murder mystery starring Daniel Craig having the time of his life as the man hired to investigate the death of Christopher Plummer. There's no doubt about it, Knives Out is the more enjoyable of the two, with an all star cast including Jamie Lee Curtis, Chris Evans, Michael Shannon and Toni Collette, all of them on hilariously good form. It's also a welcome return to the genre after Kenneth Branagh's well meaning but redundant remake of Murder On The Orient Express (2017), although alarm bells are ringing in my head after news of a sequel being green lit were recently released. Ignore that, and go and enjoy this for a couple of hours.

'Knives Out' proves that just because audiences expect something from a film does not mean that audiences cannot appreciate when those expectations are not met. Many will go in believing this to be murder mystery film, which it wants you to believe in the beginning and throughout you are still able to wonder who is behind everything, but the true story lies within one character while the star-studded ensemble cast are in minor supporting roles which they all do excellent jobs in. The film has amazing twists and an amazing political commentary on immigration, and it uses its 2-hour runtime to the fullest extent. Be sure to see this fast before someone spoils it for you.

Knives Out is a neo-noir/dark comedic mystery. The morning after his 85th birthday party which was held at his darkly quirky estate and which was attended by his wildly dysfunctional family and his kind caretaker/confidante, eccentric and wealthy mystery novelist Harlan Thrombey is found dead, his throat slit and a knife in his hand. The family is sure it's suicide, but famous and supremely, archly self-confident detective Benoit Blanc arrives on scene and senses something sinister. All the characters are overacted to a degree which makes for fast-paced and often laughable interactions. The plot wends and weaves, constantly drawing the audience in, keeping us guessing right up to the end. You won't want to miss this 2019 Rian Johnson film!

This is perhaps one of my favourite films. The film would not be the same without its amazing cast. The film feels like a comedy at times, but finds a balance to keep it serious when it needs to be.

All hail the blinding light of genius and wit that is writer/director Rian Johnson for "Knives Out," probably the best who-dunnit you're ever likely to see in this lifetime. It doubles down on Agatha Christie at her best with 99 some-odd clever threads that get gloriously tied up in bows by the time credits roll. Plus it's tongue-in-cheek serious and Coens-esque funny, both the comic timing and the wonderful casting. The whole gang's aces, especially Ana de Armas as the guileless protagonist and Daniel Craig - playing wildly and brilliantly against character - as some sort of Robert E. Lee/Poirot-hybrid super sleuth. In the words of Wayne and Garth, WE'RE NOT WORTHY!!

Fantastically Fun.    This movie is, in a sense, a tribute to Agatha Christie, Sherlock Holmes, and Clue.  It has a bit of a Murder by Death feel, as well.   Clever, witty, well written, and directed.    This is a fun time.   I was reluctant to watch this movie because it was written and directed by Rian Johnson, who I thought did a horrific job of the installment of Star Wars he worked on.  However, I am so glad I did.  Redemption!.   The plot is clever but not the movie's strength.   The movie is thoughtfully put together and the characters are delicious.   Daniel Craig affirms that he is one of the most underrated actor of our times because he can play such a diversity of roles effectively.   He is terrific as the private investigator hired to solve Christopher Plummer's (who is delightful) murder.   Ana De Armas is captivating.   Chris Evans, Michael Shannon, Jamie Lee Curtis, and Don Johnson all have you longing for more back story.  The remainder of the cast are well played.    This one is over 2 hours but times flies by.  Looking forward to the recently announced sequel.

Knives Out - 9/10. Didn't get to watch as much movies at TIFF 2019 as I did previous years, but here's the first review of the films I saw at that festival. Knives Out was a movie I was really hyped for when I first saw the trailer. And considering I wasn't the biggest fan of The Last Jedi, I was holding out hope for Rian Johnson as I loved Brick and Looper. Knives Out is a return to form and then some. Devilishly fun and cunning, it puts a spin on murder mystery films, all the while making it more of a "howdunnit" than "whoddunit." Daniel Craig is hilarious with his over the top kentucky accent and detective ways. Ana De Armas plays her role pretty nicely and delivers an innocence to her role. Chris Evans stands out as the obnoxious and rude family member, while Toni Collette provides a hilarious rich snob character. The rest of the star cast do an amazing job as well, with each character popping out on screen bringing strong screen presences and fun dialogue. A definite must watch!
Loved this movie, everybody was great.
I'm delighted to say that this movie remains a mystery until the very end, which I find to be quite rare. Highly recommended.

So, I really don't know what the hype is about. Yes, the film had great actors but the story was very predictable and I found myself a bit bored. With 'Murder Mystery' at least had a few laughs and was surprised to find out who the murderer actually was.

It's a movie that borrows a lot... and that's fine. It was a fun watch.

However, it can't decide whether it's an homage or a parody of the who-done-it genre. It's a completely derivative movie, and that's fine I guess... but I reserve 5-stars for a movie that if someone said, "That is my favorite movie of all time", It would make sense. For this movie... it's just a fun 2 hours. Nothing more, nothing less. I enjoyed it but will likely never watch it again.

The modern day Agatha Christie tale of a millionaire who dies under mysterious circumstances. An all-star cast lead by Daniel Craig as Detective Benoit Blanc. The film is fast paced and for 130 minutes, flies by fairly quickly (with the exception of about midway into the film, where 2-3 characters are then solely focused on). I found the film to drag a bit during this portion but then the third act makes up for it with the reveal. A fun ride that I would be more than happy to ride again as well as see another story with Detective Blanc if Craig or Director Rian Johnson were so inclined to spin another tale for us.

A creative, unpredictable, and well done modern day adaptation of the classic murder mystery.  A very wealthy, successful novelist is found dead the morning after his 85th birthday party.  There is a question of how the estate will be divided among the potential heirs.  The movie has good acting all around, with very good performances from Daniel Craig and Ana De Armas, and an excellent performance from Christopher Plummer.  The first 30 minutes of the film are used by writer-director Rian Johnson to develop the characters and lay the foundation of the plot.  Being a sceptic, I thought I was watching another remake of a hackneyed Agatha Christie novel.  As the movie slowly progressed, I knew I was very wrong. The cinematography and directorial style are vaguely similar to the 1972 film classic 'Sleuth'.  While all is well and good in this movie, the strength lies in the excellent script.

Knives Out is an engrossing murder mystery that starts out as a whodunnit and then proceeds to play with the viewer's expectations and curiosity. The audience is clued in pretty quickly that the movie is going to be an enjoyable ride for mystery lovers with the murder victim being a great mystery writer in a house filled with eccentricities. Add a family of inheritance hungry relatives with motives, throw in a famous detective and a nurse as a scapegoat and just like the police trooper who loves mysteries the audience can sit back and enjoy revelation after revelation as the plot makes unexpected turns. The fact that the movie focuses more on the characters and telling the story at a brisk pace than giving the viewers a Sherlock Holmes like puzzle that they may or may not solve really makes the movie enjoyable. The plot is not beholden to showing clues to the viewers, but it shows enough to tease the imagination and the audience can try and piece together the mystery, guess who to exonerate and to blame all the while enjoying the different actors' performances. Daniel Craig's magnificent performance as detective Blanc is particularly entertaining in this movie that includes and yet mocks all the favorite elements of detective stories.

As an ardent Agatha Christie fan, I was excited to watch this film after all of the hype comparing her work to this flick. Daniel Craig's performance is good enough and Ana de Armas and the rest of the cast lauded, so why the 2.5 stars off? I just find this film to be really overrated. The constant political subtexts that Johnson hammers into his films, as with his pathetic entry into the Star Wars franchise, balance out any skill shown in his filmmaking on this occasion. As this is a mystery, its solution also falls incredibly flat. Perhaps my rating is lower than it would be if my expectations were lower, but the cast, premise, and genre promised much more for me.

Satirical.  Wannabe cautionary tale.  Almost a comedy.  Dressed-up as a who-dun-it with a laudable and worthy cast, doubtless each of whom saw some facet of potential in the script.  There are bright moments where a flame is almost sustained.

In reaching for everything -- it grasps nothing.
A terrific opportunity for most cast members to stretch and grow, to demonstrate new range and reach for the kind of roles previously filled by major talents recently lost to the ravages of time.

Ultimately it is grating to watch as the off camera talent was missing or massively divided in their conceptions which forced an ineffective compromise. 

Rather like watching a 2019 'slice of life' of distant relatives of 'the Baudelaire orphans' as told by stoners -- lacking the individual magic of the stunning cast of that cult classic that so charmed and amazed in 2004.

So much potential lost between the fingers of incompetents. Reminds me of the parable told of the dog with the bone crossing a bridge who sees his reflection... and drops the bone into the water.

Someone needs to be sure that the Producer faction, the Director faction, and the Editor faction never work together again.
It just fails to gel -- can not even sustain an emulsion.

An actor as British as they come, playing a character with the most French name I've ever heard, forced to put on a deeply southern US accent, what?
and yeah, the person who did it deserves to go to jail, no moral confliction there, the way she accidentally kills him is so idiotic that she deserves to go to prison for sheer stupidity. All the medicine stuff has dropped to the floor, two very similar bottles (except for their names in massive bold texts) one bottle is supposed to be emptied into his veins, it's his medicine, the other bottle will kill him in 10 mins if injected, and she DOESN'T BOTHER TO CHECK WHICH ONE SHES PUMPING HIM WITH?!?! I have no idea what happens after the first hour but the fact that this film does not compel me to find out means that it is just not a good movie, if it's supposed to be about whether she deserves to go to jail then it's an extremely poor movie.

Even on just one watch, it's one of my favourites already - I have a feeling I'll be revisiting this a lot. I had heard amazing things about this since its release and, man, is the hype befitting. It's a brilliant 131 minutes, even if it feels much shorter than that given how enjoyable it is.

The casting is impeccable. Daniel Craig is superb in the role of Blanc, I've actually found Craig a tad hit-and-miss - even with 'James Bond' - but he is utterly superb here; even with that unusual yet definitely entertaining accent.

It's by no means The Craig Show, though. Ana de Armas is excellent as Marta, she does a lot of heavy lifting in terms of making her character's situation fully believable. She's great from start-to-finish.

Michael Shannon is top notch too, I literally always find him fun to watch - from 'Boardwalk Empire' to, even, 'Kangaroo Jack'. Jamie Lee Curtis, Chris Evans, Don Johnson, Toni Collette, Lakeith Stanfield and Christopher Plummer are all fantastic too.

The plot is enthralling, it's crafted together expertly. It reveals bits way earlier than I was predicting, which made me worry it was going to all fall flat at any moment but it kept turning out to be the perfect time to twist the story. The comedy is also very funny, I laughed a fair amount.

When renowned crime novelist Harlan Thrombey (Christopher Plummer) is found dead at his estate just after his 85th birthday, Detective Benoit Blanc (Daniel Craig) is mysteriously enlisted to investigate the mysterious circumstances. From Harlan's dysfunctional family to his devoted staff, Blanc sifts through a web of evidence alongside red herrings and self-serving lies to uncover the truth and in doing so, shows us the different points of views of the suspects. With all the hallmarks of the classic murder mystery, there are a number of twists and turns which make it a little on the long side.

What can be said said about this film that's hasn't been already? Enthralling. Daniel Craig gives a Stellar performance as a Southern detective mysteriously tasked with solving a murder. Ana De Armas and Chris Evans also give pull their weight in their respective roles. A must-watch and I can't wait to see what project Rian Johnson tackles next.
This is a perfect movie; Everything from the story to the cast is amazing. Truly a masterpiece.

It is an entertaining movie and keeps your attention. But there are a lot of holes in the plot. Just a few of the more obvious ones: Marta, we are told, is a very good nurse. But even a not so good nurse would know that if you give someone 100 mg IV Morphine, that person would suffer a respiratory arrest in a few seconds, not "10 minutes". And federal laws prohibit anyone from carrying 100 mg vials of morphine around in their medical bags. What every medical bag should have on the other hand is an Ambu bag device for ventilating the patient until the Paramedics arrive. Toxicology tests are usually sent to an outside lab, not to the Coroner's office. The report can be accessed online, and is password protected. The days of toxicology reports on paper are long gone.

Knives out is a spectacular who dunnit mystery thriller written and directed by Rian Johnson. The film contains a stellar cast with the likes of Christopher Plummer, Michael Shannon, Daniel Craig, Jamie Lee Curtis and others. Based on Agatha Christies novels Rian Johnson gives us a wild, witty, humorous and fun story surrounding a mysterious death and possible crime. The best performance is by Craig who pulls an incredible southern accent despite his British heritage and gives an charming and likeable smart detective.  Ana De Armas also gives us a delightful performance with depth and heart. But is the script with its humorous dialogue filled with political undertones, the well designed story structure that wins the day. Rian manages to keep us on the edge of our seat and guessing what's next. A great film with charm, humor, wit, an incredible cast, thrills, and a great story.
pretty entertaining from beginning to end, if you want a light humor movie that does not disappoints this is it

A wonderful movie cast and some superb references of the mystery genre in the screenplay (which plays with our minds all the time and makes incredible use of the clichés of the genre) elevates the level of this really original movie, although Jaeden Martell and Lakeith Stanfield are wasted in the vast ensemble, this does not affect the picture at all. Two last points: Ana de Armas is wonderful, so is delightful to see Chris Evans in a fresh and bad boy acting; and finally, the social commentary and critique in the refugees and immigrants are top-notch and welcome in these times.
One of my favorite movies. Great plot and one of the greatest twists in any movie

Knives Out Is A Clever Rian Johnson Whodunnit That Boasts An Intriguing Setup, Incredible Wit, And An A-List Ensemble Cast... When Crime Novelist Mogul Harlan Thrombey Becomes The Victim Of A Mysterious Suicide, Famed Detective Benoit Blanc Is Anonymously Hired To Dig Deeper Into The Details Of The Apparent Suicide. With The Help Of Harlan's Caregiver Marta, Blanc Must Discover Which Of The Wealthy Family Members Orchestrated Harlan's Murder... The Film Was Brilliant. The Writing, Plot Twists, Cast Performances, And Attention To Detail Were Immaculate In This Modern Classic. Rian Johnson's Masterpiece Is One Of The Most Well-Written Mystery Films In Current Cinema. Once You Think You've Narrowed Down Your Pick For The Killer, You're Thrown A Perfectly Crafted Curveball... This Cast Is A Dream Team. Its One Of Those Rare All-Star Team-Ups That Turns Out To Be As Flawless As The Cast Of A Marvel Blockbuster, A Jordan Peele Nightmare, Or An Ari Aster Flick. I Love That This Film Doesn't Feel Or Present Itself As A Hollywood Cash Grab. It Takes Itself Seriously When It Needs To, Trusts Its Audience, And Is Riddled With Elements Of The Greatest Crime/Mystery Films Of All Time. There Shouldn't Be Any Surprise That I'm Giving "Knives Out A Grade Of 91%!

Un elenco muy completo con actores de la talla de Don Johnson, Daniel Craig,  Jamie Lee Curtis, Toni Colette, Michael Shannon, Christopher Plummer, Chris Evans entre muchos otros que nos dan cátedra de cómo complementarse en escena con un guión fluido, inteligente y sorpresivo hasta el último minuto. 
No hay manera de hablar de la película sin dar algún "spoiler" pero la premisa es simple, se investiga la muerte del patriarca de una familia donde toda la familia tiene algún motivo para haberlo asesinado; y no puedo compartir más detalles para no arruinarles la experiencia. si bien la premisa es simple, y la hemos visto infinidad de veces, la inteligencia con la que se desarrolla la historia es magnífica, y pondrá a prueba el detective que todos llevamos dentro. Knives Out is a Rian Johnson directed flick with an all star cast based murder mystery much like an Agartala Christy novel. Daniel Craig  played a detective hired to find out who killed the patriarch of the Thrombey empire played by Christopher Plummer. All of the family members have motive to kill the head of the family starting with Jamie Lee Curtis to her husband played by Don Johnson, the other family members included Michael Shannon, Chris Evans, and Toni Collette. The center of the story is Plummer's caretaker played by Ana de Armas. Rian Johnson for once found a winning formula to make a very good movie.  I highly recommend this one it will keep you guessing till the very end.

Rian Johnson may have divided fans of the 'Star Wars' franchise with his controversial entry, but here he reaffirms his indisputable talent by returning to the genre that started his whole career: mystery/whodunit. Written and directed by Johnson, ‘Knives Out' assembles an all-star cast (everyone's great, but leads Ana de Armas and Daniel Craig really steal the show) and delivers a clever mystery that I feared was too simple at first, but goes on to introduce lots of unexpected twists (as any good mystery should) and a dose of black humour. That combination means things never get too dark or depressing and you're sure to leave the film having been well entertained, doubly so if you're already a big fan of murder mysteries as a whole.

And the whole thing is sprinkled with social justice sauce in a way that is too ham-handed.... not enough to wreck the movie, but enough to be eye-rolling.  

I suppose Johnson was going for a modern version of Clue - not exactly serious, not exactly comedy - but by trying to grab some sort of higher-order relevance by adding metaphor on top of everything else, he blows it and steps in "high-handed" instead.

Knives Out, written by Rian Johnson, is a cleverly written comedical film that leaves the audience gasping through it. This film centers around the death of a wealthy man, and a detective who is hired by an unknown source to pinpoint who is responsible for the death. Johnson uses and engaging story line to demonstrate that those in power do not always deserve it, and to show how immigrants are treated and viewed in today's culture. Unlike other films within this same genre, Knives Out leaves the audience genuinely guessing and on the edge of their seat, unfolding a story line that at its core centers around the goodness of humankind. Johnson's other work, such as Star Wars: The Last Jedi, center around a plot that is dramatic and serious. However, Knives Out incorporates humor by overemphasizing the drama within the film. This film makes a social commentary about those in power and the nature of how people view and treat immigrant families. It paints the people who are wealthy and in power as selfish and concerned only about the money and wealth that they have. Furthermore, this film makes many upfront comments about immigrant families. Having much of the plot centered around a nurse whose parents are immigrants. This girl receives several comments that attack her family. Furthermore, there is an emphasis on how pure this girl is as opposed to the people in power. All in all I would give this film two thumbs up! Cleverly written, it keeps the audience entertained while relaying an important social commentary. By the utilization of the colorization of the characters clothing to relay their personality, as well as the music and soundtrack used in showing the characters to create particular moods. The use of cinematography add layers into the plot of the film, leading to a shocking resolution. Unlike other films within this archetype the hero of this story develops overtime, and may even be given to several different roles. All in all, Knives Out is a brilliant film with an important social commentary on immigration and those with wealth and power.

A detective investigates the death of a patriarch of an eccentric, combative family (Source IMDb)

Knives Out is the perfect movie for those who love to watch a murder, mystery, and thriller movie, Knives out is a movie that has many events that take you here and there, takes you to the past and present. The movie breaks the boredom in such a simple, easy, and clever way. 

The whole cast is absolutely amazing, Ana De Armas, I was in shock by her acting and her facial expressions, she was able to put on that performance of the good/innocent nurse in a beautiful way. Chris Evans was absolutely incredible, he really impersonated a grimy and sleazy character and convinced all of us how filthy his character is that I think many of us when we look at Chris Evans all we see is "Captain America" but after watching this movie we will see the filthy "Ransom Drysdale". Finally, Daniel Craig's acting was incredible as well, his accent, the way he speaks, the way he moves around and all was just so genuinely incredible, and of course, the whole supporting cast as well was a great choice.

The script is so clever and the more you watch the movie, the more you'll discover some little details that will shock you, which makes Knives Out a unique film. The first hour of the film was so enjoyable, it'll make you just curious and want to know more but then the movie gets a bit boring in the second hour and to be specific after "Harlan's Will Scene", which makes sense because it was like a "break" for the audience especially that the first hour was filled with so many events but at the end, the movie got up again and shocked us with that great ending that I really loved and did not expect at all.

The great custom design that did fit each character so very well, Marta's (played by Ana De Armas) scarf and different costumes, Joni's (played by Toni Collette) beautiful dresses, Ransom's (played by Cris Evans) sweater or detective Benoit Blanc's (Played by Daniel Craig) different suits throughout the movie. 

The production design that was just so very beautiful, and it's shocking that the movie did not get nominated for an Oscar for "best production design". 

The music gave a movie a great little taste although I thought the movie was going to have a better soundtrack.

Knives Out is a movie that you will enjoy so much and "highly recommend" everyone to see this masterpiece, one of the best murder/mystery and thriller movies ever

From writer/director Rian Johnson comes the murder mystery Knives Out.   When Harlan Thrombey is found dead of an apparent, but suspicious, suicide renowned detective Benoit Blanc is hired to uncover the truth. Featuring an all-star cast that includes Chris Evans, Ana de Armas, Jamie Lee Curtis, Toni Collette, Don Johnson, Michael Shannon, and Christopher Plummer, the performances are especially good.  And Johnson does an impressive job at constructing the mystery, along with devising clues that lead Blanc to unravel it. Additionally, Nathan Johnson provides an exceptional score that compliments the tone and heights the tension and suspense.  Entertaining and fun, Knives Out is a captivating whodunit.

However, the problem was that the dialog was incredibly simple and at times even dumb. It felt like a 16-year-old wrote the movie. The pop-culture references were so cliché and lame that it was distracting. Katherine Langford is totally unconvincing, making the movie even more immature. If you've ever wanted to hear Daniel Craig try a Cajun accent, watch this movie. If not, there are a number of other who-done-it movies worth checking out first.

Wealthy mystery novelist Harlan Thrombey (Christopher Plummer) invites his family to his Massachusetts mansion for his 85th birthday party. The next morning, Harlan's housekeeper Fran finds him dead, with his throat slit. The police believe it was suicide, but an anonymous party pays private eye Benoit Blanc (Daniel Craig) to investigate. Blanc learns that Harlan's relationships with his family were strained: he threatened to expose his son-in-law Richard (Don Johnson) for cheating on his wife, Harlan's daughter Linda (Jamie Lee Curtis); cut off his daughter-in-law Joni's (Toni Collette) allowance for stealing from him; fired his son Walt (Michael Shannon) from his publishing company; and had an altercation with his grandson Ransom (Chris Evans). Unbeknownst to Blanc, after the party, Harlan's nurse Marta Cabrera (Ana de Armas) apparently administered him an overdose of morphine by accident instead of his usual medication and could not find the antidote, leaving Harlan minutes to live. Knowing that Marta's mother is an undocumented immigrant, Harlan prevented her from calling for help and instead gave her instructions to create a false alibi to save her family from scrutiny. Harlan then slit his own throat. Harlan's elderly mother saw Marta carrying out Harlan's instructions but mistook her for Ransom. Marta cannot lie without vomiting, so she gives true but incomplete answers when Blanc questions her. After agreeing to assist in Blanc's investigation, Marta conceals evidence of her actions as they search the property. Harlan's will is read: to everyone's astonishment, he left everything to Marta. Ransom helps her escape the family's wrath. Ransom coerces Marta into confessing to him and offers his help in exchange for a share of the inheritance. The other Thrombeys try to persuade Marta to renounce the inheritance; Walt threatens to expose her mother's immigration status. Marta receives an anonymous blackmail note with a partial photocopy of Harlan's toxicology report. She and Ransom drive to the medical examiner's office, but the building has been destroyed by arson. Marta receives an anonymous email proposing a rendezvous with the blackmailer. Blanc and the police spot Marta and Ransom, and after a brief car chase, Ransom is arrested; Blanc explains that Harlan's mother saw Ransom climbing down from Harlan's room the night he died...

Rotten Tomatoes website's critics' consensus reads: "Knives Out sharpens old murder-mystery tropes with a keenly assembled suspense outing that makes brilliant use of writer-director Rian Johnson's stellar ensemble." David Rooney, writing for The Hollywood Reporter, described the film as an "ingeniously plotted, tremendously entertaining and deviously irreverent crowd-pleaser" and "a treat from start to finish," praising the film's script, the throwbacks to the murder mysteries of the 1970s, and the actors' performances. Dana Stevens of Slate wrote "Knives Out knows exactly what kind of movie it is: a sendup of twisty murder mysteries with all-star ensemble casts that also loves and respects that silly tradition." For The A.V. Club, A. A. Dowd called the film "madly entertaining" and "an ingenious sleight-of-hand crowdpleaser". David Ehrlich of IndieWire gave the film an A−, writing "Johnson has devised a murder-mystery that's eager to defy your expectations, but unwilling to betray your trust. The film may be more smart than stylish, and it may opt for a reasonable outcome over an overwhelmingly shocking one, but Knives Out doesn't let the element of surprise ruin a good story." David Sims of The Atlantic wrote that Johnson "turned the whodunit on its head". Dani di Placido of Forbes wrote that Johnson "finds a way to revitalise the concept" and "makes murder mystery great again".

Honestly, I don´t understand the raving reviews of Rian Johnson's "Knives Out". The film received critical acclaim, particularly for its screenplay, direction, and acting, and grossed $309.2 million worldwide against a $40 million budget. At the 77th Golden Globe Awards, the film received three nominations in the Musical or Comedy category: Best Motion Picture, Best Actor for Craig, and Best Actress for de Armas. It also received Best Original Screenplay nominations at the 73rd British Academy Film Awards and 92nd Academy Awards. It was also selected by the American Film Institute and the National Board of Review as one of the top ten films of 2019. To me this is just another not particularly original whodunnit murder mystery with a nod and a wink to Agatha Christie. Nothing more, nothing less. Despite the fact that the film has a great ensemble, but that doesn´t help. Not in my book at least.

Bad people are bad, good people are good, there's no real depth here just flash.  

Pacing also seemed a little off, possibly because so many of the whodunit answers are given very early, that it's hard to stay invested in the characters trying to figure out things we, the audience, already know about. Political movie masquerading as a mystery. The director, actors, and scriptwriter are all open left progressives. Knowing that and watching the first 5 minutes of the film you can figure out the rest of the plot and the ending including who "did it."

Cliched and has too many characters for its own good, it would have been much more refined with a smaller cast involving those with the more interesting backstory. The first 30 or so mins set up a motive for every character, some exposition is required but seemed strained in this movie.

This makes figuring out whose child is who confusing and unnecessary, especially with a short time frame. The large casts seems like a convoluted attempt to disguise the obviousness of the perpetrator.  Attempts at humour fell flat for me personally. This is one of the better movies lately, mostly due to the well-developed personal points of view of the main characters. It had classic potential if only transitions had been done with more supporting enhancement/emphasis, including the use of background music, character-depth close-ups with accompanying nonverbal expressions, and some youth flashbacks. There were elements of these enhancements, but for transitions that would have made scenes unforgettable, these types of enhancements were very subtle or missing.

One example is when Blanc is singing to himself while waiting in the car, his character could have been more comedic and the overall scene improved if he had been visualizing himself performing - an actual scene of his playing and singing to an audience from his point of view - completely oblivious until someone knocks on his car window and shouts at him very loudly for some reason, at which time he would first become aware of the ambulance.

One part of the detecting scene with Blanc and Marta is done perfectly, when Marta tosses the broken piece after the dog gave it to her... while Blanc is staring through the window at Greatnana Wanetta. I felt like I was hungering for more of that type of humor.

But in the soup of things, this movie has more meat and a wider variety of content than most.

Knives Out is American director Rian Johnson's fifth feature film. This self-authored mystery is suspenseful, absorbing, and uproariously funny. Though I didn't recognize the director's name before now, I've since discovered that Johnson is a rising star with a reputation for innovative script writing and direction (Star Wars Ep 8: The Last Jedi, Looper, Brick). In addition to movies, he has also taken on some television work, most notably directing three episodes of the acclaimed series Breaking Bad for which he won a Director's Guild of America Award in 2012. 
     First and foremost, Knives Out is a classic whodunit movie, and bears all its hallmarks. It takes place mostly in one location, the palatial home of best-selling mystery novelist and murder victim Harlan Thrombey (Christopher Plummer). Several of Harlan's progeny, including in-laws and grandchildren, have plausible motives to commit murder. However, the death on which the movie centers, appears to be a straightforward suicide, and is treated as such by the police. That is, until the sharp sleuthing powers of private investigator Benoit Blanc (Daniel Craig), begin to uncover another story. 
     Of the many delights this film offers, one of the best is the offbeat casting. The ensemble of top-notch actors, spanning many eras, genres, and media seem to be having a great time playing roles that are, for the most part atypical for them. Daniel Craig, for instance, best known as the seventh James Bond, here plays investigator Benoit quite credibly with all the mannerisms of a Southern Gentleman including, as one character puts it, "that Kentucky Fried Foghorn Leghorn drawl." Don Johnson of Miami Vice fame, is entertaining as the philandering son-in-law Richard, husband to Jamie Lee Curtis' severe and sardonic Linda. Chris Evans, erstwhile Captain America, plays the couple's entitled and malicious son. But the movie belongs to Ana de Armas who plays Marta Cabrera, the sympathetic nurse to Thrombey. Cast into this maelstrom of unexpected events and incriminating clues, she needs to summon her wits to try to stay one step ahead of the investigation. Cabrera is, by turns, vulnerable, funny, resourceful and strong. 
     I can go on about the sparkling dialogue, enjoyable acting, and clever plotting but THE ONE THING that radiates from this film for me is the accomplished, cinematic storytelling which is achieved largely through precise, layered editing. Johnson has collaborated with editor Bob Ducsay on his last three films and they obviously have developed a very effective, efficient and smooth method of narration. For instance, shortly after the film begins there is a 16-minute interrogation scene in which we meet all the principals and hear their take on the events on the night of the murder. Not only does Johnson deliver exposition but he exposes a rich tapestry of scandals, lies, insecurities and attitudes. It's achieved largely through the richly nuanced script but also through rapid cutting from present to past and back. Sometimes one character speaks to the investigator. Blanc replies with a reasonable question. Then that question is answered by another character who is unexpectedly now sitting in the interrogation chair. One would expect this to be jarring, but it is pulled off so seamlessly that all the narratives are blended into one intelligible, detailed and entertaining story of the Thrombey family. 
     My favourite scene occurs when Marta and another character collaborate to cover-up an unfortunate accident. Marta is given detailed instructions on what she must do to extricate herself from blame, and as she receives this information, we see her performing the steps. But this is not merely a voiced over scene. Marta has trouble recalling some of the instructions clearly, and the voice over now garbles the instructions too, to reflect her confused state. She even talks out loud to the voice over, and the character responds. Then the scene cuts to the investigator completing a coin flip in the air, letting the audience know that all of this detailed recollection happened in the space of time needed to flip a coin. This brilliant blurring of memory, subjectivity, suspense, and time is typical of the style and pacing of this extraordinary film. 
     Knives Out is an exhilarating film made by a director at the peak of his powers, and delivered by a radiant ensemble of actors old and new. The formidable gifts of Johnson and his crew are pressed into the service of providing audiences with a brain tingling experience that never stops being fresh and fun to watch.

Knives Out is a sleek and stylish homage to genre cinema and a great reminder of why Johnson is one of the best writers/directors working today. There's so many essential elements of the classic murder mystery from the conspicuous victim, an ensemble of two-faced elitist suspects, a gothic setting, and an eccentric detective. In lesser hands, Knives Out would become more parody than homage, but the script is lean and brilliantly thought out while also delivering plenty of laughs and great performances from a stellar cast.

Franchises and reboots have become the norm in cinema today. That is precisely why Rian Johnson's wholly original, meticulously crafted murder mystery is all the more refreshing. Featuring a starry ensemble cast and a terrifically sharp score, Knives Out is filled with exciting twists and turns, the result of which is a whodunnit worthy of Agatha Christie.

A whodunit that both praises and spoofs the genre (in meta format), Knives Out is wonderfully entertaining, even if some of the characters serve more as archetypes instead of human beings. This film is still pretty new, so I'm not going to spoil the ending, but about halfway through it takes a lovely turn from a typical whodunit to a cat-and-mouse, but with many more twists to come. The cast is star-studded, with Chris Evans, Jamie Lee Curtis, Michael Shannon — who I would watch do anything — and Daniel Craig, whose accent is just ridiculous enough to be believable; his baseball throw, however, belies his southern drawl. Toni Colette, Lakeith Stanfield — who I swear is in every movie I watch nowadays — Don Johnson, and Ana de Armas, who I wouldn't say steals the show, but is the nicest surprise, are just a few more to add. As you can see, there's a lot to unpack here in terms of characters, so I'm not going to bother with names, but basically a rich crime novelist is dead with a slashed throat, a famous PI is hired, anonymously, and it (mostly) takes place in a gorgeous Victorian home with the coolest study I've ever seen. The film is also a snapshot of the times, with terms like "Alt-Right Nazi, Lifestyle Guru, et al." being used amongst the characters. The best running gag was how each character said de Armas was from a different country — Paraguay, Uruguay, Ecuador, Brazil. Of course, have to mention that circular knife centerpiece that is never directly addressed, but plays a larger role than just general badassery. Maybe I'm just a big dumb dumby, but why couldn't the detectives just ask de Armas if she committed the murder? I'd go into more detail, but said earlier about no spoilers. Comment if you know the answer. Knives Out delivers exactly as it should, which is sometimes all I want in a movie. Pairs great for a date night and red wine.
Craig's accent takes a while, but it doesn't detract from the premise or execution of the story. Worth a watch, but it's no Poirot!

With special homage to Clue & Murder on the Orient Express, Knives Out is a murder-mystery. Knives Out is a whodunit that's visually appealing, fresh, and fun. 

Every detail leaves audiences chasing breadcrumbs and guessing who is the perpetrator throughout. While it's common to assume who's responsible, we learn that every detail given is as important as the last. Audiences' suspicions will change continually throughout the film in an organic way.

Though Rian Johnson created this masterpiece, more special appreciation to the absolute A+ cast in this film. In such a star-packed film, it's surprising that chaos no one actor claimed most of the screentime. Special shout-out to Daniel Craig's (fake but hilarious) southern drawl, Chris Evans' as the prodigal son, Jamie Lee Curtis as the tough-as-nails mogul, Jaeden Martell as the young alt-right jerk, and the rising stardom of Ana de Armas & Lakeith Stanfield and many more. Everyone in the cast seemed to have real fun and chemistry throughout the movie. And the audience shares in the absolute amusement of viewing this movie.

This movie has an incredible star-studded cast with spectacular performances across the board. Standouts include Daniel Craig and his Kentucky accent, Chris Evans telling people to eat sh**, and Ana de Armas with easily the best performance in the movie. Not only does Rian Johnson do a great job with directing this movie, but an even better job writing it.

However, the movie mistakenly goes against the murder-mystery formula. We're given too much information too early, which makes the last half of the movie less interesting. The point of a murder-mystery is to play "detective", analyze the characters and see if you can figure out whodunnit, but this was spoiled for us too early. Even still, this was a clever, well thought out movie with great characters and a fun storyline.

Movie in Summary: Good

Recommended for: Fans of murder-mysteries, fans of Rian Johnson subverting your expectations, or fans of Captain America telling you to eat sh**.

Story/Screenplay: (3.5/5) A nice whodunit.  Original, yet harkens back to more traditional suspense dramas.  The suspense is decent and maintains interest throughout the story.

Duration/Tempo: (3.5/5) At 2 hours and 10 minutes, it's a very long movie that felt shorter, but it was still long.  Would have liked to see some trimming to get the overall length down.

Cast & Crew: (4.5/5) Daniel Craig and Ana de Armas were excellent and the overall cast was impressive.  Very good performances across the board.

Summary: (3.5/5) The cast was excellent, the story was good, and the film didn't feel as long as it was.  A thumbs up.

PLEASE NOTE: Just want to make a point- There is just as much "review raving" (Hired studio hacks, it is their job) than "review bombing" (in which no one is paid in the first place).  Most reviews here by audiences are NOT considered in overall RT audience ratings because our ticket purchase hasn't been verified via Fandango and other sources.  I still like to read any audience review if trying to decide if I want to see a movie.  I skip most critic reviews except Rex Reed-he's been around a LONG TIME and has probably seen more films than any other critic. Just my  2 cents: If not printed on RT, then I'll never be back, as I think audience reviewers need to understand this issue. Bottom line: if you don't prove you saw a film, your review doesn't count, but critics don't have to prove they saw a film. 
REVIEW OF FILM: "What were the words heard by the Nazi [listener] masturbating in the bathroom?" is screenwriter/director Rian Johnson's funniest line, and the answer resolves much of this beautifully done murder mystery.  Daniel Craig delivers that line (as Detective Benoit Blanc) with a nicely rendered southern America accent (great job by vocal coach Diego Daniel Pardo). But Craig keeps thickening his accent, much to the entertainment of admiring cop Noah Segan, but not so much to Segan's cop partner, LaKieth Stanfield. During the final 'big reveal', these three plus the final suspect along  with the great Ana De Armas give us a masterpiece of acting. Add the magnificent Jamie Lee Curtis, Toni Collette, Christopher Plummer, plus others, and you have THE great film ensemble cast of the year. Not to mention the very creepy Jaeden Martell. Set Decorator David Schlesinger creates a fun/creepy house, Special Effects Supervisor Judson Bell keeps any special effects unnoticeable, a superior effort for me as I don't like effects drawing attention to themselves and taking me out of the film/story.  Rian Johnson comments in the extras that his main focus was making a movie, and oh does he succeed. This is entertainment of the highest order, and easily my favorite film of 2019. And how could you not laugh out loud at Craig delivering another great line: "You [the final suspect] and Harlan [the murdered Plummer] were drama mamas," ironically delivered by Craig has he reaches a crescendo of his Southern 'act'  which is the center of the film, and may have been indeed another layer of the mystery. I watched this twice in a row (the second time with comments) and there'll be a third watch soon. This isn't just a murder mystery, it's a movie masterpiece. And yes, that's the Rolling Stones' performance over the end credits with a great score recorded at Abbey Road Studios in London. If you think movies aren't as good as they used to be, you're gonna be in for a great surprise. I hope, soon, to see a movie poster/DVD cover with the words, "Another Rian Johnson WHODUNIT." Dame Agatha Christie is praising Rian Johnson from the literary heavens, surely.

Rian Johnson wrote and directed this movie and shows off his talents as a filmmaker. "Knives Out" is a fantastic "whodunnit" murder mystery movie. The cast is phenomenal. Christopher Plummer plays an old mystery novelist, whose death is being investigated by Daniel Craig's Detective Benoit Blanc. Craig steals the show every time he is on screen. Craig's southern accent is very convincing and his whole performance is memorable. Relative Hollywood newcomer, Ana de Armas, is the lead in this film and although she is surrounded by veterened actors, she definitely does falter and gives a great performance. The supporting cast of Jamie Lee Curtis, Chris Evans, Michael Shannon, Toni Collette, and LaKeith Stanfield round out one of the best ensemble casts outside of the MCU. The story is gravitating. It is about Blanc being mysteriously summoned to investigate the "suicide" of Plummer's Harlan Thrombey. There are several moving pieces in the story and every character seems to have a motivation for killing Harlan, but also for not wanting to kill him. The conclusion seems a bit more predictable as the film progresses, which is a bit of a let down. I was able to predict fairly early on what the end would be, but it is still such a fun ride that it makes it okay. The cinematography is fantastic. Bright colors and engaging scenery make this feel like a Clue game come to life. The dialogue is sharp and really all of the characters are interesting and fairly fleshed out. This is not the absolute best movie out there, but it is well-made, acted, and written to warrant it's high praise. Overall, I give this movie an 8.5/10.

Finally! A mystery movie that I can even compare to Clue (go watch that too). This reminds me a lot of what the detective from "Murder on the Orient Express" is supposed to be.

One of the things that really makes this stand out as a "dinner theater" piece, is that almost everyone is unredeemable. Instead of everyone is innocent until proven guilty, everyone is presented as a guilty (as a suspect, at least from an audience stand point), and we have to piece together the clues as we're drip-feed information.

And as the movie continues, it reminds you where you might not have been paying attention, rehashes events in the logical manner that is required, in case you hadn't followed, to prove the case (again, baring semblance to "Clue"), and every detail and every minute of the movie is intriguing.

I'm looking forward to the 2nd watch to see if the re-watchability holds up.

It was pretentious and a tribute of the author, director, producer of the film. Rian Johnson projects himself through the role of Benoit Blanc. Initially, the investigation is lead by a young, equally intelligent detective, whom has his role usurped by the older Blanc because the black detective has no entre into this wealthy upper class cast of suspects. Within the first minutes of the movie, the interviews  help you figure out who killed Harlan Thrombey, (which in a successful movie is a no-no). 

The Games of Thrones-like throne is another feature that shows Johnson's arrogance. While you can tell that he loves mystery and film noir, his mis-use of cinematography through-out, (in a failed attempt to "highlight" clues), is probably a tribute to old school mystery writers and the famous genre director Hickcock, is a part of this arrogance; Johnson has a myopic belief in his skills. His flat script reminds me of his other movies that are clearly his cinematic monument to his ego. Which even they are a veiled attempt to hide the fear he must face, having failed early in his career, that he will never truly write his "great work", direct his "great epic" nor acheive his place in history as a significant contributor to the movie industry itself.

Knives Out had Rian Johnson's hand all over it! He directed, produced, and wrote the film, just coming off of Star Wars: The Last Jedi, that was pretty controversial, but bounced back very well with a definitive mystery classic. Not only did he create one of the best mysterys to come to the big screen, but he was able to incorporate all of the enjoyable genres like crime, drama, thriller, & comedy. Johnson painted these beautiful frames, adding so much depth to his shots. With shooting in detail, rather than in film, it added a lot of depth to every scene, while utilizing the natural light that was provided.

Rian Johnson did a phenomenal job modernizing the murder mystery/who did it tale, and really making it his own. The screenplay was coherent & fresh, being so witty, sharp & hilarious. He created this crystal clear narrative, backed up with so much wit, and style, it made you overlook all the simplicities. The few subplots this film had, it added amazing layers & depth, while it all intertwined with the big picture so well, enhancing this great mystery tale. The tone switch ups this film had was incredible! The tone switched up every half hour or so, keeping us on our toes, but explaining everything in depth, while keeping it as entertaining as possible.

Mary Vernieu casted easily the best cast of 2019 so far. Knives Out was chock-full of A-list actors like Daniel Craig, Chris Evans, Jamie Lee Curtis & more! Everyone knew their place, and played their roles the best they could've. Christopher Plummer put on such a mature & witty performance, arguably being one of the funniest of the group. Daniel Craig was one of my favorite castings for this movie. His performance was very witty, and clever, mixed with great tongue & cheek jokes. Craig may not have been the main protagonist we follow, but he is most certainly one of the best performers in this movie! Ana de Armas was our sweet "innocent" main protagonist. We follow her for most of the film, and my god, does she put on a GREAT performance! Chris Evans has been more focused on playing a cool headed, heroic character in the Marvel Cinematic Universe, but here he puts on a devious, sarcastically funny, yet charming & persuasive character. We got a little taste of him in the first act, but not as much as the other supporting characters. Evans becomes more present in the second and third act, adding a different flare to this unique family. Rian Johnson created great tention with all of the characters, throwing in nifty twists, keeping everyone involved, and relevant.


The art directors & production designers in David Crank & David Celestenger created this beautiful, old time mansion. The way Rian Johnson executed the mansion was fantastic, making everything feel free, yet claustrophobic, while rising the stakes.

Overall, I can easily say this is my favorite mystery movie, even over Sherlock Holmes; Highly recommended.

From the impression that I received, several reviewers that I trust thought that Knives Out was an excellent movie, and given that 2019 wasn't exactly an astounding year in film, I was convinced to watch it as the diamond in the rough I was led to believe it was. The good? An all-star ensemble cast of A-list Hollywood actors headlines this piece, and with exception to Jamie Lee Curtis (whose last acceptable performance was in True Lies), they all play rather well the part of the cartoonish characters that this film needs in the setting it constructs. And wow, the house in which most of the film takes place beautifully illustrates the ugliness, dysfunctionality, and schizophrenic nature of the family at the heart of the story, so when the film is setting itself in the beginning, the camera allows the audience to see strange statues, odd architectural structures, and rather mundane items all right next to each other. The bad? The movie lasts an hour too long; the "truth" is revealed less than halfway through and all of the wind is taken out of its sails, but Rian Johnson keeps dragging the movie along to force the audience to see that "No, that's not really what happened" to showcase his faux cleverness as Daniel Craig plays the detective that conveniently figures everything out in record time. The injection of pop politics (i.e. lines like "They're putting. Children. In cages.", "Anchor baby.", "Your mom is still undocumented", multiple usages of the phrase "the help") took me out of what was occurring in the film, making me think of real-life events but not the movie while realizing that that'll inhibit its shelf life when people watch it 10+ years from now. Lastly, Ana de Armas' allergic reaction ("if I even think about telling a lie I start to throw up") takes an intentionally absurd plot and blasts it into ridiculousness when she begins lying by omission early in the movie yet doesn't vomit. By the end of this, I was more than ready for it to be over as I had long since grown tired of its American Beauty level of pretentiousness. If you want a better film with similar tone and tenor, go watch Clue, and if you want to watch a mystery that takes its material more seriously yet has lots of twists and turns, I strongly suggest watching the first two seasons of Broadchurch, but avoid this movie if possible.

It intertwines comedy, mystery and manages to be a thriller at the same time. It switches genres at the flip of a coin and makes you laugh at the drop of the hat. The music is incredible and the cinematography (The shot that is lit by Blanc's cigarette, straight out of Casino Royale is incredible) and editing (The shot in which Ransom tries to kill Marta and inconspicuously moves into a slower frame rate) reach epic dimensions and still manages to seem up close and personal.

Daniel Craig is perfection, Chris Evans doesn't miss a beat, Jamie Lee Curtis has some weak moments but still gives a great performance, Katherine Langford is believable and the biggest revelation of this movie was Ana De Armas who (almost) managed to keep up with Craig and Evans.

The movie was also very fun. There were a lot of pretty fun moments, but not too many that it becomes a problem. The cast is of course really great, and I enjoyed the technical aspects of the film as well. Overall, Knives Out creates a great atmosphere and kept me on my toes, but never took itself overly seriously.

A well-crafted, decently-written and greatly-acted homage to classic whodunnits in the vein of Agatha Christie's that ultimately fails to bring anything new to the genre. The plot is not the brightest ever and the characters are stereotypical and pretty much two-dimensional which will probably make the film feel a bit weak to hardcore fans of the genre but will certainly appeal to viewers less familiar with this type of narrative. The stellar ensemble cast feels somewhat wasted with most of the film being focused on newcomer Ana de Armas and her great performance as Marta Cabrera, the innocent immigrant nurse with a golden heart, and the pintoresque detective Benoit Blanc, charmingly portraid by Daniel Craig. Ultimately, the film delivers and it certainly doesn't disappoint but to veterans of the great mystery novels, like myself, it feels like a good but bland effort.

For those who love classic whodunits, this is a most welcome surprise. Daniel Craig is a convincing Southern US version of Hercule Poirot, the other cast members are equally good (Chris Evans - Captain America - can actually act!), the story is original and surprising to the final minute.
