*Mild spoilers*

Turns out that this one reveals its hand too early. That fatally deflates the surprise and suspense for the majority of the runtime. The quest-to-prove-one's-innocence parallel could've been deliciously executed if it weren't played as obviously. I kept waiting for a big twist to flip 'Knives Out' morally on its head, but the characters, while flamboyant, are kept disappointingly one-dimensional. Everyone who is first introduced as good remain good and those presented as rotten remain rotten. I equate this movie to 'La La Land' in the sense that many people gave it credit/longed for it to be something that it wasn't quite - possibly because of its overt political message. The promise of the star-studded ensemble is suggested early on, yet never fulfilled since an unanticipated side character becomes the protagonist. 'Knives Out' plays it straight when I was expecting something much twistier and darker. I had sky-high hopes for this and, while it still passably amuses and showcases some of Johnson's skill, 'Knives' is a much splashier, broader mystery than his bewitching debut, 'Brick'.
Was expecting a mystery, this was just predictable and boring

An old, rich writer is ends up dead in his house. He's old and sick, so that's not that weird but there is something fishy about his death so an investigator is snooking around it a bit. He has a big family. And they are like vultures - they can collect loads of cash after his death and they fight a lot over it. He's greatest friend is a young nurse that also takes care of him - she is also in the mix and is by my perspective the protagosist here.

Loads of known faces, an interesting and well crafted cast. It's a very interesting crime thriller with a murder to solve. It's also funny and makes most of it moves right with some nice twists. Always developing and interestingly so.

The acting is great and the lovely Ana De Armas shows that she is more than just the pretty face from the nevest Bladerunner film. Solid film that plays it safe and smooth.

This is one of the most anti-white movies I've seen in a while. It makes the white family degenerates and the illegal immigrant nurse the good person. Great murder mystery.

𝐒𝐮𝐦𝐦𝐚𝐫𝐲: An extremely wealthy and famous novelist is murdered in what appears to be a crime of passion on the night of his 85th birthday party. While his large family of dysfunctional narcissists grieves over the loss of their father, their selfish anxiety seethes in anticipation for the unveiling of his will. The family hires a detective (Craig) to uncover the events leading up to their father's untimely death, who conducts a myriad of interviews ladened with lies, deceit, and varying recollections that don't quite add up the way they should. 

A trope murder mystery drama with a touch of black humor that does a fine job succeeding within its clear unique genre. This Clue-inspired classic Agatha Christie whodunit film unfolds dissimilarly to most other films within the genre, which is arguably its greatest strength. 𝘒𝘯𝘪𝘷𝘦𝘴 𝘖𝘶𝘵 consists of finely woven web of twisted family relationships and narcissistic superiority complexes that makes for a dazzling array of characters. The acting is fine, with a standout breakthrough performance from lead actress Ana de Armas. However, I found Daniel Craig's performance to be overrated and sloppy with a painfully distracting attempt at a vintage southern gentleman accent that just didn't do it for me. Admittedly, I may not have received this one quite as highly as consensus, but I found it to be a perfectly enjoyable film that wasn't afraid to take chances and embrace its own unique style.
I wanted to like it more. The cast would have suggested that this would be a blockbuster. Decidedly average for me.
The acting is far better than the mystery. I was sure who the killer was from the beginning of the film. Plays out like a middle of the road Agatha Christie.

"Knives out"
The film combines dark humor and the classic whodunnit tale. It has an interesting story that has you glued to your seat.
The cast includes people like Chris Evans, Daniel Craig and Ana de Armas, which makes the cast very good, making the movie charming and you can enjoy it most of the time.
Also, the script is full of changes that make the plot of the story dynamic, therefore, when you think you can guess what follows in the story, something comes that I'm sure will surprise you.
In addition to all this, the soundtrack of the film makes each scene in perfect harmony and makes you stand at the end.
Brilliant. From the script to the costumes, everything matches the aesthetic and the final plot. The movie is a work of art.

Una clásica película de detectives. Rian Johnson hace un guión muy entretenido y lleno de giros en la trama. Un historia muy estructurada y con personajes muy bien elaborados. Un suicidio o un asesinato? Y si fue un asesinato, quien es el asesino? El abuelo dueño de la fortuna de la familia muere, de una forma muy extraña y cada miembro de la familia podría tener un motivo para querer muerto al abuelo. Y por supuesto un detective será el encargado de descubrir quién fue. Todo desde la perspectiva de la enfermera del abuelo. Actuaciones buenas de un elenco de actores muy reconocidos destacando la actuación de Ana de armas que hasta ahora creo que es su papel mejor logrado. Una historia que te divertirá y te mantendrá atento a cada instante porque tú también querrás descubrir quién fue el asesino. Un género del cine que nunca aburre.

That was AMAZING! I regret not watching it sooner, but I'm so glad I finally got around to this movie. This has gotta be one of the most hilariously clever films I've watched in such a long time. Such a fun plot. Everything came right back around to everything previously mentioned in the movie, and just after my third viewing did I realize how many clues were left in the plot. A spectacularly clever play of words that came out in the last act just made me want to die with laughter. As a "who done it" movie, I felt like early on I knew exactly who the culprit was, despite the efforts the movie tried to make to throw me off, but I was racking my head a million times trying to conceive how the suspect could've done the crime even though the movie explained it very early on who was mainly responsible. And yet my expectations were subverted beautifully. And as to the cast, Daniel Craig, Chris Evans, and Ana de Armas were just perfect. They deserve every bit of praise the y got. And as an extension, the entire cast was amazing too. 4.7/10 HIGHLY Recommended if you want a good mystery comedy.

-->SAFE SPACE! NO LAST JEDI POLITICS IN THIS REVIEW!<--
Knives Out is a good old-fashioned whodunit that's confidently directed, acted well, is intriguing, is paced well, is shot well and is hilarious thanks mostly to Daniel Craig and his hilarious over-the-top Southern accent complete with unorthodox vocabulary to boot. Nice to see Chris Evans play against type as well...or is he? The only problem? The advertising because you know Hollywood wanting to hide the fact that Ana de Armas a.k.a. the girlfriend from Blade Runner 2049 is the protagonist, not the Thrombeys or detective Benoit Blanc. But since that seems to have been an intentional move when you watch the movie, it doesn't really qualify as an actual criticism. That, and the fact that I can't talk about more without risking spoilers. So, go watch it and learn why "Ruin Johnson" is a dead meme!
Even funny, along with all the other murder mystery attributes. Even why the detective is there is a mystery.
The best plot I've ever witnessed.

This was really fun and enjoyable. I loved how all the pieces started to come together. I loved Chris Evans being the bad guy, which is hard to imagine after seeing him play Captain America over the years. But I’ll take off half a star because it started kind of slowly. I remember at one point checking to see how much was left and I was only a little bit past halfway.

A fun film to watch. Something I feared wouldn’t be coming from the divisive Rian Johnson. His treatment of Star Wars is infamous by now, creating rifts within the SW community. That aside, Knives Out is a great nod to the classic star studded Agatha Christie films from the ‘70’s. Very stylized and bright with a new twist on the “Mystery Mansion” genre, it was satisfying to watch and fun to see the clues come together. The cast is a dream, Craig has created as quirky and odd a detective as Poirot or Marple but with more of a sense of reality. Really a beautiful film to watch and a very odd script to match. Worth the buy in my opinion and I hope we see Benoit Blanc return.
It's just awesome like everything makes sense

Menuda sorpresa ha sido la de Knives Out. Vale que este tipo de tramas inspiradas en Agatha Cristie son una delicia para un servidor, pero creo firmemente que Ryan Johnson ha realizado un trabajo portentoso en esta cinta.

Para empezar el guión funciona bastante bien, y aunque es algo sobreexplicativo en algunos momentos (y posiblemente alguna mente más fina que la mia encuentre algún agujero que yo no supe ver), te consigue mantener atento y no te ves venir muchos de sus giros. Y creo que los detalitos a la cultura popular y política americana del momento, aunque a veces obvios, son interesantes de ver reflejados.

El casting es, obviamente, fantástico con y practicamente todo actor hace un trabajo estupendo. Don Johnson vuelve a mostrar su vena cómica una vez más, lo mismo que Daniel Craig y Chris Evans. Pero sin lugar a dudas la estrella es Ana de Armas, que se carga a cuestas la película con su personaje emocional que logra que te preocupes por ella durante todo el metraje.

La edición es digna de mención también.

Más cintas como estas Ryan Johnson, por favor.

Knives Out was a well-paced, amusing film that attracted all audiences with its whodunnit theme. A good range of actors delivered the stereotypical character personas well while twists and turns kept us entertained. Craig's acting definitely offered a welcome stray from Bond, while the strength of his accent might have not quite turned us all on. 
Where it succeeded? A dynamic pace, cinematography & a well thought out setting.
A smudge of rot? At times, over-the-top comedy tropes (hum *vomit*)

ok, so!....The D of P was cruel. I don't enjoy seeing every single actors pores. He even made Daniel look like asphalt. And he shoots from too low, up at people - it's just not attractive. I also knew the vials were switched and there was no murder as soon as that scene played out, I was alerted by the antics of "pretending there was an earthquake", knocking over the board and the shot of the vials falling. (And why did harlon have a chemo port installed for a daily injection for a hurt shoulder?)  I knew it was a "who done it" that wanted a twist desperately and I knew that meant Harlon was alive or it was actually a suicide. Also, if Harlon was willing to slit his own throat to save the nurses mother and sister from deportation, and he had already given her his entire estate-it seems odd he wouldn't have just hired an attorney for $4000 a while ago to make her family legal. Especially since he was very sharp still and managed his own finances and those of his entire family. (Also morphine hits the Brain 3 seconds after it's injected at 30 times the dosage! Lol) I also knew Chris Evans was guilty as he was hardly in the first half of the movie and a star of his caliber wouldn't take the role if he weren't pivotal and had a big scene at the end. And Daniels accent was KFC. Watching shenanigans for two hours knowing the vials were switched and there had to be no murder ...waiting for captain americas big moment for his pay check was not over the top fun. I mean...she runs an Errand to get the medicine bag back With the detective in the car? And what she's gonna do? - just carry it out and throw it in the trunk with him in the front seat? And also...as soon as she over dosed harlon I said well, the tox report will show it was an overdose so why are they doing all this other shit. Anyway... 97% of people enjoyed it so good for all of them! For me and my husband, since I told him every thing that would happen, a bit of eye rolling. But I LOVED that house!!! What a great location!!! Oh...and What was with the Game of throws set piece?!...I knew that spot was in for a big finish and I also knew that fake knife gag would come back as it was also kind of clunky dialogue that stood out in the death scene. So I saw it all coming. This is the closest to perfection a film has come in a long time. Knives Out is a well written, brilliantly acted and superbly crafted mystery that captures the old-fashioned Agatha Christie whodunit vibe with a modern twist. Rian Johnson uses his genius to tell a hilarious, clever story in a delightful and totally entertaining way. Every second is accounted for as there's not a moment where events don't take a wild and unexpected turn. But deep down it's the message of kindness that really sticks along after the credits have rolled.

That's not how you do a Christie-style mystery. Wayyy too many family members, which was so sadly unnecessary as none of them were focused on. There weren't motives for everyone - absolutely not - and one review said there were alibis! There weren't. The detectives had no characters - I couldn't tell if we were meant to like them or not. They only focused on forensics, not people's motives and attributes that might steer them towards murder. They only interviewed like 3 people at the start. If they couldn't fit the other family members into interviews, they clearly weren't suspects so there was no point in them. They say this is a classic who-dunnit, but let's be real - there were like 15 characters, and only 2 suspects. You find out half of the murder details 40 minutes in!!! There were only 2 good parts: the reveal of Marta's role in the death, and then the plot twist reveal. I can't remember anything else. But someone tell me why they had iPhone XS Maxs (2018) and then videotapes that I haven't seen since 2007.

The film doesn't take a lot of time for set up and sets the pace right through. In simple words one if the best thrillers I've ever seen, also the scenes between Christopher and ana are well executed

Knives Out is a masterclass in storytelling and redefining a genre that has been done to death (pun not intended). By subverting the narrative, Rian has created a piece of work that will stand the test of time and engages its audience to question everything that's presented to them. 

It boasts an excellent cast with Daniel Craig and Ana De Armas at the centre of it. Being a big fan of Daniel as James Bond, it was interesting (and thrilling) to see him in a different role. I will say his accent takes some getting used to if you're familiar with his original accent. However, that dissipates as the movie goes on. Ana gives a performance that'll push her into more main roles.

Chris Evans is delightful as the "black sheep of the family". For someone who has played a morally sound boy scout for nearly a decade, it's refreshing to see him be someone who swears and doesn't give a hoot about what people think of him.

If you've yet to see, Knives Out, you're missing out. Whether you enjoyed Rian Johnson's previous film is a totally different kettle of fish as Knives Out is an original piece that shows how talented he is as a Director and a writer.

Knives Out é escrito e dirigido por Rian Johnson, e meu amigos... que trabalho magnifico que ele fez aqui. Esse filme me faz sentir sortudo por ser um apreciador da Sétima arte!

Sabendo disso, fica claro que o fato de ser escrito e dirigido pela mesma pessoa faz uma grande diferença. Nós sabemos que seremos surpreendidos, e a direção faz isso de proposito para que ponhamos nossa cabeça para funcionar. Mas nada é entregue de bandeja aqui, não até o gran finale. O filme apresenta todos os personagens para que comecemos a nos basear desde o principio. Mostrando as discussões pendentes e com quem o velho tinha mais afinidade. Obvio que determinados aspectos são revelados de acordo com que a trama segue, e devo dizer que o timing foi excelente, visto que você não se sente cansado em nenhum momento do filme. Cada cena é importante e nada é atoa - guardem bem isso.

Daniel Craig estava excelente nesse filme. Talvez essa tenha sido sua atuação mais divertida, pra mim. O papel dele não é fácil, pois entrelaçar o misterioso, o divertido, o espertalhão e ainda dar corda para o filme acontecer - sem ele, não haveria sequer caso - é um peso e tanto. Já Chris Evans usa de todo seu charme para construir um personagem arrogante e pretensioso. Ana de Armas convence muito no seu papel, passando drama nos momentos corretos e seguindo sua linha de base até o final do filme, o que mostra muita atenção por parte dela. 

Entre Facas e Segredos é um prato cheio, principalmente para quem gosta do gênero. Surpreende, intriga, atiça, e tem um final extremamente satisfatório.

'Knives Out' is a quirky mystery thriller riff rolled into one gripping, ingenious package by director Rian Johnson. His vision here is firmly tongue in-cheek as it subverts some classic genre troupes in surprising, funny ways but remains razor-sharp to a point of being its own suspenseful mystery; with some gorgeous visuals and charismatic cast only to be topped off with a very relevant social commentary that doesn't derail the film's lighthearted tone. It's sensational and destined to be a classic! - 9/10 (A-)

Knives Out seems hellbent on making us gasp, and going "Ahh, that makes sense". It is obvious that Rian Johnson has proofread his script a million times, and although it is airtight, its subversions are wholly unnecessary. Unlike TLJ, twists are seen as essential in a film of the "Whodunnit" genre, so Johnson's habit is excusable. But now that he has the excuse of a mystery film, it seems he has turned the proverbial dial to 11 and has gone all out with his twists. These happen so often that I found myself disappointed and flattened by the films climax. To add to the irritation, there is the obligatory underlying immigration message which directors feel obliged to put in their work for it to have a deeper meaning. But when this cannot be interwoven with the film's own plot and theme, and instead is just happening at the same time, it loses all reason to be in that film in the first place. Despite this, the film certainly has its merits. Everyone fills their roles well, the characters as a whole are well written and the movie has an attention to detail which is commendable. Johnson has certainly come up with a stellar idea for a film, and its intrigue is certainly still alive, but some restraint was desperately needed. But from the start I knew this would be an easy crowd pleaser. A needed career booster, if anything, for Johnson. And who am I to critique him for that?

This movie feels like a half-hearted remake of the 1980's version of Clue and tries to hard at being quirky when it just isn't; a house full of quirky souvenirs doesn't quirky make. Lastly, the script just doesn't hold up for mystery fans. At the end I was left asking myself "there's a twist here, right?"

I loved everything else.  Pacing, interleaved plot twists, keeping score of Who's The Primary Suspect, absence of any deus ex machina, and above all the play within the play:  the film never really confronts the "She planned it all, every little thing" scenario a true Go mistress could perhaps imagine, but it's there if you want to think about it.

Rian Johnson is one of those rare writer/director filmmakers who is looking to redefine movies. He turned the Star Wars universe on its head with The Last Jedi, delivering what is close to the best Star Wars film in the saga. Now, he sets his sights on updating the Agatha Christie whodunit thriller for the modern era. The film has a strong cast, and a storyline that's quite simple in nature, but that's the fun and nothing is never what it seems. I was expecting something overhyped and pointless, but this is incredible. Rian Johnson is playing at the top of his field and it's refreshing to find a filmmaker attempting new things. In the Whodunit drama, detective Benoit Blanc (Daniel Craig) has to uncover who killed famous author Harlan Thrombey (Christopher Plummer).

Acting: 10
I can't speak enough about the amazing performances that made this movie come alive. I honestly don't know where to start or who had the best chops because they were all so wonderful. Jamie Lee Curtis has always been one of my favorite actresses and her role didn't disappoint here. She's Linda Robinson who serves as somewhat of a matriarch in the family. She delivers her lines with such perfect timing and such fluid grace that it's hard not to love her character. I also appreciated Jaeden Martell's role in the movie. I can only imagine how hard it is as the youngest cast member when you have all these heavy-hitting stars beside you, but he definitely held his own by putting on a performance here that was even better than his role in It, in my opinion.

Beginning: 10
You are immediately thrown into this story from jump like you are springboarding into the sky. The intrigue is immediate which gave me an instant feeling that I was going to like this movie. It's a perfect setup for what is to come.

Characters: 10
Nothing short of spectacular. Again, where do I start? I love that every single one of these characters in the movie have a rich story that's connected to the deceased. There is also some kind of growth (whether negative or positive) with each character which is hard to juggle when you're talking about managing runtime as well as screentime. I could pinpoint one specific role, but I loved each and every single one of them. That's not a very common thing to say.

Cinematography/Visuals: 10 
Director Rian Johnson really hits home on the visuals with an interesting blend of vivid colors and bleak imagery. I have a great appreciation with how the movie was ultimately cut. It's a film that doesn't rush, but takes its time, really capturing special dramatic moments. It almost feels like a Wes Anderson meets Stephen King type of cinematic adventure.

Conflict: 10

Entertainment Value: 10
From shock value to mystery, Knives Out keeps you on your toes start to finish. It's funny, it's smart, and, most importantly, it's original. This kind of movie has been done dozens of times before and this one is, by far, the most unique of the bunch. It truly is in a class of its own.

Memorability: 10

Pace: 9
With a 130-minute runtime, it's only natural that there would be a slip-up in pace here and there. Fortunately, the slowdowns are very brief and barely noticeable. I can only think of one or two moments where I thought, "They could've cut that." The momentum is pretty incredible otherwise.

Plot: 10

Resolution: 10
Ends strongly, yet smoothly with a finite resolution. I found it funny that the ending was actually a subtle knife into the hearts of the antagonists. The conclusion is a beautiful whisper.

Overall: 99
Knives Out is hilarious yet touching at the same time. With an original storyline, consistent pace, and brilliant characters the movie succeeds on just about every level. It was both refreshing and unexpected to watch a movie this grand.
Movie left me speechless from beginning to end. Awesome movie

Tortuously labyrinthine plotting aside, this is a gloriously enjoyable and very well-acted pastiche of Agatha Christie, set in a gloomily underlit old dark mansion in a wintry Boston, where a deliciously vindictive family are all suspects in the murder of their moneyed father. Or was it suicide? Rian Johnson - writing and directing - fashions a claustrophobic and clever movie, consciously nodding at Mankiewicz' Sleuth and Lumet's Murder on the Orient Express while having fun too at the expense of mobile phones, VHS cassettes and even - in Daniel Craig's marvellous Southern detective - Stephen Sondheim.

Rian Johnson's murder mystery comedy Knives Out (2019) is a fantastic bit of intense suspense and silly nonsense to entertain you for 131 minutes of pure joy. Knives Out is easily Johnson's best film to date as his writing is intricately detailed with fun foreshadowing of major plot points as he allows the audience to guess alongside the detective. It's like a neat interactive viewing experience wherein the mystery is part of the fun as Johnson delivers clue after clue to help cross off suspects and glue pieces together to culminate in a blissfully complex narrative. Knives Out's murder mystery is unpredictable and subversive in the best kind of way: refreshing. Johnson's script uses contemporary references and upbeat pacing to keep you engaged with the dialogue, so that you remember every detail due to his delightful phrasing.

Johnson's direction is similarly astute. Rian Johnson finds the heart and motivation for each of his quirky characters and lets scenes breathe in a refined and classy like his previous films have not reached this caliber of filmmaking. Rian Johnson establishes himself as an auteur with his own voice, style, and vocabulary for modern audiences with the outstanding picture Knives Out. I highly recommend Knives Out, if only to witness Johnson come into his own as a director of original content and playful knowledge. He uses intimate spaces in production designers David Crank and Jeremy Woodward's mansion set with efficient cleverness. You are always wondering what lies underneath each clue setting up for another twist.

Bob Ducsay's editing is phenomenal for Knives Out. Each moment sweeps you away with a shocking cut utilizing image matching and verbal cues to transition you to another fun moment. Ducsay has a flourish and flair to his editing that keeps Knives Out tight and fast. The 131 minutes feels like 30 to me. Steve Yedlin's cinematography is fascinating and fun too. His framing is so clearly focused in to characters, reactions, and feelings as he captures countless clues in the backgrounds and tiny hidden figures all over Knives Out. The camera work keeps people in beautiful shots and unique poses, so that you are misdirected and led on a curious path deeper into Knives Out's mystery.

Nathan Johnson's score is playful as he teases you with cute musical cues to clues throughout Knives Out. His music is pretty, but how he contributes to the mystique and humor of Knives Out is his real accomplishment. Jenny Eagan's costumes are wonderful with Ana de Armas and Chris Evans donning instantly iconic cable-knit sweaters. Meanwhile, every other character gets adorned with colorful dresses and stylish suits. I just love the look of Knives Out as everything looks comfy and warm for such a cold mystery movie. Luisa Abel did a wondrous job putting make-up on Ana de Armas making her up to be even cuter.

Speaking of Ana de Armas, she absolutely steals the show in Knives Out as the lead actress playing a sweet nurse named Marta Cabrera. Armas leads the fray as Knives Out's leading lady with heartfelt compassion, emotional openness, paranoia panic, and gentle grace. She expresses such a wide range of emotions in Knives Out that I was sincerely impressed by one of her greatest roles. Knives Out is all the more fun with the inclusion of her cute persona Marta. Ana de Armas has been astonishing me for a few years now after she genuinely acted her heart out in Hands of Stone and Blade Runner 2049 alike. After Knives Out, I am all the more intrigued by this gorgeous and talented young actress portraying Marilyn Monroe in Blonde next. She is a force to be reckoned with now.

Rian Johnson pulled out all the stops to stuff Knives Out with a killer cast of all star actors. Including Ana de Armas, Daniel Craig also leads Knives Out as the stern and silly Souther detective Benoit Blanc in one of his funniest roles. His accent alone is consistent and hilarious, but it's Craig's brilliant comedic timing that keeps you laughing. He effortlessly allows himself to be both the genius sleuth akin to Sherlock Holmes or Hercule Poirot as well as the foolish detective like a deep fried detective all his own. Likewise, Chris Evans is pitch perfect as the almighty asshole Hugh Ransom Drysdale. His smug smirks and cozy cable-knit sweater clad entitled rich jerk is delirious fun as he insults the entire world of arrogant wealth surrounding him that he's also apart of in reality. Knives Out is one of Daniel Craig and Chris Evans' best roles, honestly.

Jamie Lee Curtis is neat and fierce as the very direct and particular Linda Drysdale. Don Johnson kills it as the cheating husband of Curtis named Richard Drysdale. I was surprised just how much I enjoyed Johnson's demanding conservative character. Michael Shannon is outrageous as the fearsome, manipulative Walt Thrombey. Shannon can play it kind and attentive, then suddenly switch to naive and curious, then vicious and underhanded in an instant. I liked Jaeden Martell as Shannon's Neo-Nazi, alt-right teenager Jacob Thromboy.

Furthermore, Toni Collette remains one of the greatest actresses of all time as the adorable shallow and self-serving Joni Thrombey. Katherine Langford is excellent and convincing as the sincere stoner feminist and simultaneously selfish rich girl Meg Thrombey. Her portrayal is really a nice touch of depth for several character arcs here.

In addition to the aforementioned actors, Lakeith Stanfield continues his career dominance as the fun and skeptical Police Lieutenant Elliott. Christopher Plummer is still iconic as a calculating mystery novelist and intellectual millionaire Harlan Thrombey. His playful chemistry with Ana de Armas is a highlight for me from Knives Out for sure.

Riki Lindhome has a cameo as the passively racist conservative Donna Thrombey. Edi Patterson gives a good performance as someone going out of consciousness. Fozzi Bear himself, Frank Oz, himself cameos as the will reader Alan Stevens in a very funny scene. Lastly, K Callan stars as Christopher Plummer's mother Greatnana Wanetta in a neat little role that has dire consequences. Her absent minded role delivers several huge laughs and a few sweet moments alike.

In short, Rian Johnson's Knives Out is a stellar feature film with an inventive script, innovative editing, focused direction, and an unreal cast. I hope viewers give Johnson's greatest film a chance.

Two stars - "Meh, it passed the time." A perfect encapsulation of how I felt about this movie. 

The attempts to make jokes often fell flat, and frequently relied upon breaking the fourth wall when doing so by saying what we are supposedly thinking (as one character notes, "I mean, the guy practically lives in a Clue board"). 

Daniel Craig's Southern accent was offensively bad and often took me out of the movie. It's like they wanted to get Kevin Spacey and his Frank Underwood Gullah low country drawl, but decided at the last minute to get another actor following Spacey's scandals.

The interview scenes seemed to have lasted an hour, though possibly 20 minutes in real time, without changing the setting of the plot (minus the flashback scenes). It was a very long section of the movie and it felt like the story wasn't going anywhere.

Finally, the amount of deus ex machina given to Daniel Craig's character was absolutely absurd. He somehow figured out the entire murder-suicide in painstaking detail without first revealing this to the audience, so it seemed he conjured up the resolution of the story out of thin air.

I'm glad the movie ended shortly afterwards.

Rian Johnson, I must take my hat off to this man. He created what many fans of mystery and crime were looking for: An excellent script, an intellectual cast, top-notch cinematography, and great soundtrack.

Note the original story, which was the product of inspiration for other adaptations classics such as; Clue, Murder By Death, Murder on the Orient Express, Rat Trap, among others. It was incredible. The characters were amazing, from the victim to the suspects.

Can we take off the hat before the only and talented Daniel Craig? I did not expect to be surprised by the interpretation of James Bond in this film. I expect a sequel soon, with Daniel on board.

And a loud applause for Ana de Armas before her convincing interpretation as Marta! It was also fun to see Chris Evans doing something other than carrying a shield with a star on his chest.

BRAVO FOR THIS PRODUCTION!

Spoilers for both Knives Out, and all Star Wars Sequel Trilogy movies (7-9):
*I do agree with the message of Knives Out, which shares strong themes with Rian Johnson's Star Wars 8: The Last Jedi. This message is that your identity and merits as person, should be defined by your own actions. If the best way to define yourself is by the merits of your ancestors, then you are evaluating yourself wrong. 

Your biological family means nothing towards who you develop yourself as a person, and shouldn't automatically make you heir to anything, if you don't deserve it. In a way this film brings the closure to Star Wars 8: The Last Jedi themes in that it carried on the conclusion. The JJ Abrams' written and related, Star Wars 7: The Force Awakens and Star Wars 9: Rise of Skywalker don't have themes of their own; and basically try to justify their merits on being tangentially related to the George Lucas' Star Wars movies (the end of Rey saying: "I'm Rey Skywalker" is basically Rey saying all my merits hinge on me knowing this more successful person). Worse is that to give that completely wrong and pro-nepotism message, the good Rian Johnson's message was retconed away. That message is that you are worth something regardless of coming from nothing; in both instances.

Knives Out as a criticism of both JJ Abrams' films and all the whole expanding movie franchises shared universes (like comic originated MCU and DC); trying to justify their merits and whole existence by being tangentially related to other movies without nothing of worth to say on their own.

Knives out is advertised as a whodunit movie. In a way it sort of is but this is Rian Johnson, he loves subverting expectations. Seriously though, this movie really subverts a lot of expectations. It's better to go into this movie with little to no knowledge which is why it is difficult to review this without giving away too much.

First off, this movie has an amazing cast with Daniel Craig pulling off an American accent as the private investigator. Chris Evans post Avengers work has him play a much more terrible character which is a huge contrast to Captain America. Christopher Plummer while a minor role gives a very lovable mystery novelist. Jamie Lee Curtis, Michael Shannon, Don Johnson and Toni Colette give a very convincing performance as egotistic rich snobs. Ana de Armas must be praised as well for being able to convincing give the audience a sort of POV character in this massive all star cast. I will also give props to Lakeith Stanfield, Katherine Langford, Jaeden Martell and Noah Segan as well as they did a great job as well. The story and the screenplay is just phenomenal with the witty and charming dialogue. Likewise, the twist are smart and really keep the audience on its toes.

I do struggle to find negatives but I guess the one and only true blatant negative is the very obvious political message. "Right white conservative" are bad. The movie doesn't emphasise it a lot but there are scenes where is delves into these such as immigration and having the white rich characters talk quite negatively about it. Likewise emphasising how the children of Christopher Plummer's character have not earned anything of their own legitimately or have been given massive money to earn anything. It's a very simple and obvious message that anyone can see throughout the entire film. Additionally, maybe the misleading advertisement can be quite a deterrent to some viewers. As stated at the beginning, Rian Johnson completely flips the Whodunit genre on its head but the trailers and advertisement suggest it is just a typical whodunit story when it really isn't. To me this isn't exactly a negative but it could be seen as such to other viewers. 

In conclusion, this is a must watch to everyone. It is such an entertaining movie and is a great reminded of films from the old Hitchcock days. While the director's previous work, The Last Jedi, was divisive; This movie is amazing. Give it a watch!

Knives Out plays like a good old fashioned murder mystery of the highest order, achieving a delicate balance between characters and locations that feel like frontrunners from an Agatha Christie classic, while also grounding its story with an aesthetic and dialogue that feels relatable. I walked into to this movie having not seen many murder mysteries in the past, so I was worried that I would walk away either very confused or having a feeling of missing out on something. I can tell you however, that this is far from the case, Knives Out has quickly become one of my favorite murder mystery comedies I have seen in some time. There is simply so much that makes this film great in my eyes, from the amazing acting from the cast, to the screenplay, to even the little details that come back into play perfectly through the story, I was left guessing until the very end, and even better I was left in stitches by the surprisingly funny writing and dialog. This film was a pleasant and truly great surprise of 2019, If there are any imperfections, they are minor, and I had didn't even notice any if at all while watching this film. Knives Out is a magnificent ride and one that I highly recommend viewing, a true must see of 2019, I give Knives Out an outstanding 10/10!

I really enjoyed this film. I'm not great at mysteries, so the story felt kind of confusing to me the first time I watched it–it definitely required a second viewing–but it was still entertaining. The cast was amazing, and I wish they'd gotten more to do all around (Toni Collette especially), but I was particularly impressed by Ana de Armas's performance and am happy she got as much screen time as she did. I expected to find Craig's character grating but I actually found him fun (in a ridiculous way). I especially appreciated the production design and general direction–the house was a formidable setting for this story and Johnson is one of my favorite directors right now. I am happy to be able to watch and enjoy original scripts, especially those that offer a reflection on our current political/cultural dynamics. I think this story is hailed as more astute than it actually is–I saw a great take on Twitter about this, that while a film like Parasite offers an upending of the structure that oppresses poor and working-class people, the story in Knives Out doesn't ultimately threaten the system–the unsavory players are just replaced by more virtuous ones. Heard there's a sequel coming–if that's the case, I hope Johnson continues to follow this thread and deepen his reflection. I'll definitely pay to watch it.

Knives Out (2019) captures the tone of a perfect murder mystery, from its constant editing to different characters perspectives, flashbacks with narration and repetition of those sequences. Of those characters, they are all played well by a brilliant cast, who even though are selfish people, make the time with them amusing and enjoyable. As fun as the untangling of the mystery is with this films quirkiness, the story to Knives Out (2019) is brilliant, subtly laying pieces for the culmination in the end.

Whenever sequences were on the verge of overstaying their welcome, Rian Johnson's directorial style and script would switch things up into a fresh environment, whether that is literally the location or exposition making the two-and-a-half runtime feel shorter.

To perfectly sum it up, Knives Out (2019) is a very clever movie, from its story to the character portrayal thanks to wonderful actors, it is both fun and intriguing, making for an energetic murder mystery.

The movie felt like it didn't know what it wanted to be. It couldn't decide whether it was a whodunnit or not. (It really wasn't) It couldn't decide whether it was a comedy or not. And most importantly, for a clue-style movie, it didn't focus on its characters enough. The jokes were funny and subtle, but there were long segments that didn't make any attempt to be funny. Towards the middle of the film, I was getting more invested in the drama element of this comedy. It felt like it was constantly bringing up new plot lines then throwing them away. Finally, it has a classic "massive plot twist at the end" that barely makes sense and relies on information we didn't have.  On the plus side, they keep a very consistent mood, and the film seems very high quality. The characters are mostly likeable in their own way. This was a fun movie to watch. Oh, and how was this PG-13? I don't have a problem with swearing, but the swearing was very heavy in this one.

"That certainly not what I was expecting."

- Whodunit?
- Rian Johnson.
- Why?
- To subvert the tropes of yet another sub-genre... properly!

As divisive as it was, I neither loved nor hated the love-it-or-hate-it The Last Jedi. Maybe because I'm not a huge fan of the much-beloved saga. But I can give you a quick opinion of what I thought about it anyway. The first half almost turned me off completely: tons of lame jokes and out-of-character moments that indicate that Johnson's biggest concern was to subvert expectations and nothing but. The second half of the film was way better. It proved to me that Johnson is actually very capable of adding fresh blood to the saga, so effortlessly to such an extent that I wondered why he struggled so much in the first half.

In Knives Out, Johnson didn't add a new spin on the 'whodunit' sub-genre of detective fiction; he took it and turned it on its head. He did so not only by playing with the tropes and mechanisms of this sub-genre -and boy, he did that so exquisitely and gracefully- but he also by using a new and very effective building block: Drama. It doesn't sound new, isn't it? But, actually, relying on it here, in this kind of a story, is nothing short of revolutionary, and that's simply lies in the fact it's unprecedented to build upon it here. The result is nothing but marvellous. And although that, at some point, the main concern of the plot wasn't the murder mystery per se, the mystery didn't lose its sharpness even a tiny bit. And that's a strong proof that everything worked, and integrated, seamlessly. I said integrated because the film has a plethora of comedic bits throughout its runtime -which flies by- and, to be honest, I think every single joke landed perfectly. The film also suggest a political agenda that's exquisitely woven into the plot, and provides a sharp social commentary that's impressively subtle.

Not only did Rian Johnson reinvigorate this seemingly outmoded and unfruitful sub-genre, but he also did the same thing with a couple of members of the star-studded cast: I didn't know that Chris Evans, Captain America himself, would be better as, well, an "Anti-Captain America "; Craig as Blanc is absolutely phenomenal, with his southern accent and caricature detective character; and Jaeden Martell (IT) is very interesting as the weirdo Jacob Thrombey. As for Curtis, Langford, Plummer, Collette and Shannon, Johnson makes an excellent use of their incredible acting abilities, and of their facial expressions and features, especially Shannon with his remarkable menacing countenance. The real standout, though, is Ana de Armas. I mean, she was good in Blade Runner 2049, but here, as she plays my new favourite version of Pinocchio, she proves she's an exceptionally talented actress who is capable of expressing emotions, and changing them readily, only with her eyes. Honestly, I think she should have been nominated for an Oscar!

Overall, I'm really surprised how much I loved this film. With Johnson superb and clever direction and meticulously-nuanced and witty -albeit slightly too-structured- screenplay, I think this is my favourite - even if it's not my highest-rated - film of 2019. You know what, this film is actually terrible: it's very pretentious; its puzzle is too convoluted for its own good; it has an overabundance of plot twists; it underutilized its stellar ensemble; and it has a lot of plot holes, or -in this case- donut holes! Excuse me, I gotta leave right now!

Rian Johnson subverted sci-fi fantasy with (arguably) the best star wars film in The Last Jedi, pulling no punches for his love of the genre and material but not without forward-thinking ambition, and now he's returned to the mystery genre to do the same with the sharply-written and playful Knives Out. Johnson clearly loves the genre and he fills his mystery box, a stunningly crafted Massachusetts Cluedo mansion, with all the tricks of the trade and some of his own making. The result is murder mystery throwback to Agatha Christie that comes screaming into the present with modern insecurities and viper-tongued social commentary. It's a blast.

The easiest way to grab an audience's attention is to kill someone and Johnson does precisely this is the opening minute of his clever film, having poor maid Fran (Edi Patterson) stumble upon centrepiece of the conflict Harlan Thrombey (Christopher Plummer), a successful crime writer himself, with the unfortunate affliction of having his throat cut. The film then unfolds in a sort of documentary style at first with each family member interviewed by two detectives, their names revealed by title cards, their testimonies full of red herrings. This is done against the backdrop of an extravagant, wildly impractical display of knives – and so the game is afoot.

The detectives believe it's a routine, albeit unconventional suicide. But there's another mystery in the room, sitting at the back in the corner, shrouded in darkness, the elusive, eccentric Benoit Blanc (Daniel Craig), an old-school detective whose presence is a mystery unto itself. He doesn't know who hired him. Craig is funny and brilliant as the oddball investigator, equipped with a played-up southern drawl that has him nick-named CSI-KFC – and so begins the barrage of self-referential humour that trickles throughout the script like expertly placed breadcrumbs. It's a delight to see Daniel Craig freed from his bond shackles and disappear into a role – and loving every minute of it.

The rest of the cast don't disappoint either, each of them overplaying their hyper-realised characters. Michael Shannon is Harlan's eldest son Walt, playing a sensitive, sniffling publisher to his father's lifetime works, and is understandably miffed when daddy decides to cut him loose in one of the most passively aggressive shutdowns you're likely to see. His wife is the rather quirky Joni played by Toni Colette who joins the rest in being well cast because she always has that side-eyed look of somebody that's a little wild and unhinged – perfect for a murder mystery. Black sheep of the family is Ransom, Chris Evans playing against type as an arrogant brat, swapping his Captain American costume for warm knitwear. Jamie Lee Curtis is excellent as eldest daughter Linda, given quotable lines that see her poke fun at the media frenzy that is twitter. Her husband, Richard (Don Johnson) is a trump supporting sleazeball, his scenes often made to cast commentary on the racial divide happening in America, particularly when contrasted with MVP of the film Marta Cabrera (Ana De Armas), a South-American "friend" of the family and nurse to Harlan Thormby. I very much enjoyed the political undercurrent of Knives Out as it gives the film a welcome bite and the excellent script is likely to reward multiple viewings and an attentive gaze.

It's good to see Armas getting the leading role and attention her talent deserves and she delivers in spades here. Her character is at the centre of the mystery that unfolds, and with the waspish commentary of class division that's trickled throughout and brought to a perfectly realised boiling point in the fantastic final shot, her presence is a tricky yet helpful thorn in Blanc's side as he uncovers the nefarious deeds that surround Harlan's death. A death that provides a neat table flip halfway through the film and forces the audience to reconsider the central mystery in a new light. And this is where I think Knives Out shines brightest as a murder mystery because it becomes clear towards the end that Johnson is less concerned with the surprise shock of a final twist and more interested in the best way to execute the unravelling of his tangled web of mystery. This is what makes Knives Out such a refreshing sweet, it is not simply a case of trying to guess who the murderer is because Johnson's hand is craftier than that, and he manages to stay a step ahead of the audience all the way. It's the sign of a great writer and once again he has surprised and re-shifted a genre that was too easy to predict. Bring on the next instalment that sees Blanc sniffing through Cornwall, investigating death by pastie asphyxiation or something. I don't care, I just want another one.

Two dimensional cardboard cutout characters, flabby script, and plot holes so big that even the slightest critical thought makes them comical. Rian Johnson writes for a low intellect-self righteous audience that demand little and he accommodates them accordingly. Johnson's real world lack of ability to socially interact with people translates directly into his films. The 'good' characters are the embodiment of purity moral selflessness, they have no complexity beyond simply being good. The 'bad' characters are greedy and selfish and are evil just because they want to be evil, again there's nothing more complex than that. It's a child's view of the world from the mind of someone who never really grew up and resonates only with rejuvenile audiences. The official critics response is case in point!

Someone got murdered. The suspects are those who were close to the victim, and they each have their own motive but only one went further than the rest. The climatic big reveal cannot be predicted, even if you have followed clues like an unmatched detective. So, what makes the latest whodunnit scenario "Knives Out" anymore significantly worthwhile? Well, it is no mystery when attracted by the cast and what sort of wit they would twist, bury and unveil upon themselves and deflecting upon others.

This modern-day murder mystery finds renowned mystery writer Harlan Thrombey privately dead at his estate just after his 85th birthday, and mysteriously enlisted Detective Benoit Blanc investigates Harlan's dysfunctional family and devoted staff only to find their own covers as one of them is red enough to see through. Or is it? We have a caretaking nurse, a housekeeper, an eldest daughter running real estate with her husband's support, a youngest son running the publishing company with his wife and alt-right bratty son's supports, a widowed influential daughter-in-law caring her daughter's study, a spoiled and hated playboy grandson, and an elderly-disoriented mother. Whodunnit, and why exactly?

Obviously despite the circumstance, "Knives Out" is fun to be engrossed by as a freshest take on the genre. The excellent cast made the story attractive, and the result shows how they had delved into their characters producing convincing family dynamics as the main characterized portion. Meanwhile the more nonfamilial upfronted serves as the story's plot-stirring and the most conflicting side. Daniel Craig's performance perfected the given role with slick charisma, right next to his singled-out co-star of the bunch Ana de Armas in her more apparent breakthrough performance. Even dead, Christopher Plummer's character still looms in the mind, therefore providing recognizable grizzled gravitas.

The star players played out the whole whodunnit mystery scene very nicely because they were impeccably directed. Rian Johnson seems to find better storytelling fitting when on his own whereas cinematic independent aesthetic is more accepted rather than pressured to take for an intellectual property – although his work for "The Last Jedi" greatly integrated his authorship stemmed from independent filmmaking, much to the displeasure of many moviegoers who only attend visually-exciting blockbusters. While his previous mystery throws back to the classics amid constant buildup, he actually went and reveal what really happen while the plot still thickens during and after. What makes it a freshest take is how the unexpected culprit's conflicting morality between honesty and loyalty whilst leaving the detective to keep pondering as diversion. Johnson more this time proves how crafty he can stretch from visual cues for distant narrative fun to genius characterization preparing for the still-yet-to-be-unveiled twists – with little political talk being ever accurate.

In terms of originality, "Knives Out" is a perfect sendoff for the year 2019, and to an extent of the decade's mainstream cinema, into the new decade by being ingeniously entertaining with an excellent cast sweepingly refreshing a classic genre structure that maintains intrigued engagement. Outside a franchise, this is Johnson's best and declared auteurism of defining his [clear] way of storytelling. But he has made potential as well sparks interest to follow a detective's further crime-solving embarkment. (A-)

Knives Out is a very fun, highly stylized whodunit following an investigation of the mysterious death of crime novelist Harlan Thrombey (Christopher Plummer) with his family and a caretaker serving as prime suspects. The stellar ensemble cast which include Jamie Lee Curtis, Chris Evans, Toni Collette, Christopher Plummer, Michael Shannon and Don Johnson among others are manipulative, dirty, downright diabolical and fun as their trifling behavior throughout is a complete treat. However it is Daniel Craig as private detective Benoit Blanc that charms every second on screen and Ana de Armas as caretaker Marta Cabrera that carries the emotional weight of the film. Its 2 hour and 10 minute running time feels much quicker thanks to the many twists, turns and hilariously witty dialogue written by the films director Rian Johnson that keeps your undivided attention. As we're winding down in 2019 and approaching award season, this is shaping up to be a stellar year in film and Knives Out is without a doubt one of the years best examples.

I've been a huge fan of Rian Johnson since the Brick days and was pleased after the bashing he got from the vitriolic, entitled wing of the Star Wars ManBaby fanbase, that he bounced back with an original little indie, to much critical acclaim. 

It starts slow and not very engaging but it picks up immediately when the true central conceit of the film, and probably the reason why it's so vibrant and resonates with critics so much, comes to light. Ana de Armas has a key role, not shown in the trailers, and the film seems nestled half way between a retro Agatha Christie and a really really good modern TV series. It's nice to see a low-fi, subtle picture that allows its characters and dialogue and self knowledge if its genre to delight instead of effects and whizzbang. 

I have to say I bumped it down half a star (or maybe even a full star) because Haymarket's Odeon is horrendous, the screen tiny, dark and cloudy, the audio tinny and plonked all over the place. It's a shame that bad projection can tarnish an experience but it did. However I'm really really looking forward to watching it again at home and that counts for something in this one-and-done age of viewing films. 

The film is enjoyable and dark and funny and fresh. It's not astounding, but it plays very cleverly within its genre and with its audience but it never lambasts or lampoons them, it says something important about privilege and entitlement but doesn't cram it down your throat. 

Daniel Craig is excellent, clearly he's sick of playing damaged, dour, anti-role models and is acting up a storm and we're all loving it too. It's not a smug film, it's lovingly cheap feeling and tangible, and it's got some genuine standout callbacks and moments in it that will be remembered in film annals for a long time. 

A compliment in many ways to TV's Succession, a timely and exceedingly welcome joyride.

Witness for the Prosecution (1957) was the perfect example of a witty, whip smart adaptation of a murder mystery that featured hilarious performances and writing that knew just how far to push the innuendo. This film drops the courtroom drama element of that film but as a group of colorful, funny characters slowly reveal their backstories and have charming exchanges you can't help but smile. Seeing that there is a place for this film in the modern box office landscape was heartening as it proves that there is still a hunger for films that focus more on writing and performances than quick gratification and this film deserves the Academy Award nomination it received.

Harlan Thrombey, Christopher Plummer, is a rich novelists who writes murder mysteries but he is murdered when he invites members of his family to his estate for the weekend. Renowned detective Benoit Blanc, Daniel Craig, is brought to the estate to investigate the case and begins to question every person who was present at the time of the murder. Of particular interest to him is Thrombey's son-in-law Richie, Don Johnson, whose multiple infidelities were exposed causing him great embarrassment in the process. His ideas about the case are confounded when nurse Marta Cabrera, Ana de Armas, is left all of Thrombey's money and assets in his will and the family turns on her. Hugh "Ransom" Drysdale, Chris Evans, is mistaken for Cabrera by one his family members, who dislike him for being a womanizer, so he arranges to pin all blame on Cabrera. She is awkward when interrogated by Thrombey which further arouses his suspicions and her attempts to conceal evidence are often unsuccessful. Blanc deduces what the most scheming member of Thrombey's family had done at the last moment and clears Cabrera of any guilt which allows her to continue living her life in Thrombey's mansion.

What was most surprising to me was that de Armas, who I have been underwhelmed by in the past, gives a capable and likable performance in the central role. She is asked to carry most of the emotional weight of the film and as she tearfully apologizes as Thrombey dies or gazes at her mother from afar you become sympathetic to her. She handles the comedic elements of her role with aplomb but her talent is really grounding the film in reality when surrounded by performers who are playing it very broad. Of course there is a wonder to seeing Toni Collette play a spoilt, new agey woman who gets too drunk at a party and starts dancing in front of a tight lipped Jamie Lee Curtis but at some point the film needs to be more than just celebrities having fun. Blanc is possibly the least interesting character in the film but that worked for me as films like Murder on the Orient Express (2017) place too much emphasis on the detective and not enough on the wacky suspects.

The film does manage to make you hate the members of the Thrombey family while still laughing at them as they are such spoilt, entitled brats that it is hard to appreciate their redeeming qualities. We initially think that Ransom, who is enigmatic and all knowing, may be less awful than his family members but the twist, which most audience members probably saw coming a mile away, allows us to understand that they are all equally toxic. Rian Johnson really twists the knife when the family members turn on Cabrera, of whom they had been supportive up until that point, and it is then that we see how patronizing they are. Many murder mysteries deal with class and while not as perceptive as Gosford Park (2001) this film wrings a few more laughs out of it's jokes about the entitled wealthy.

Despite this I think the film runs a little too long and Johnson could have cut out a few scenes of the Thrombey family simply being obnoxious or removed some of the characters. This may just be me but I also found the gag about Cabrera vomiting when she lies gross and not particularly funny and I wish he hadn't placed it in the film so often. These are minor complaints but the brought the film down a little bit for me.

'Knives Out' (2019)
This is a very solid murder/mystery. I recall seeing the trailers and promotions for this film and was very excited due to its star-studded cast. Everyone in the film does a great job and the script is very well-written. I will say however that I believe much of the talent in this film was unfortunately under-utilized, in my opinion. While avoiding spoilers of course, we get some good screen-time with each individual character early on in the film, although during the latter half of the film it really ends up revolving around only a few certain characters. Speaking of the latter half of the film, it goes in a direction that I just felt very mixed on. As I said, no spoilers, but it does not go your traditional 'murder-mystery' route at all, and to many that may be refreshing, and Rian Johnson now has a track-record for "subverting expectations", although I just feel very uncertain about the decisions with the screenplay. Daniel Craig and Chris Evans are certainly my favorite parts of the film, whenever they were on screen I was captivated. As far as technical aspects go, it is very well shot, the editing is seamless and the pacing is structured nicely. There isn't much else I can really say without delving into even slight spoilers, but overall it's a film I wouldn't mind seeing again, despite some of the gripes I may have with the plot-points and the route that the film ends up taking early on. I'd recommend it, and who knows, perhaps upon further viewings my favorability of this film may change for the better, although as of now this is how I feel.

Knives Out is one of the most ambitious and also one of the best cinema adaptations from Agatha Christie novels. We have a austere but funny Jamie Lee Curtis, an intriguing Daniel Craig, a mysterious Chris Evans and in general a cast that absolutely elevated the quality of every scene. Rian Johnson has jumped genres throughout his career — the noir Brick, the comedy of The Brothers Bloom, the science fiction of Looper, the big blockbuster that was Star Wars: the Last Jedi and now Knives Out. He also helmed an episode of Breaking Bad that won him a directing Emmy.

Since 2005, Johnson has had this Agatha Christie-influenced film in mind. He also cited films like Deathtrap and Clue as cultural touchstones for this movie.

So what's it all about? Well, crime novelist Harlan Thrombey (Christopher Plummer) is found dead — a suicide — at his estate the day after his 85th birthday. Detective Benoit Blanc (Daniel Craig) has been hired by an unnamed party to investigate the crime. From Harlan's dysfunctional family to his devoted staff, Blanc sifts through a web of red herrings and self-serving lies to uncover the truth behind Harlan's untimely death.

First things first: my attention span has been ruined by a steady diet of grindhouse movies, Hong Kong cinema and the works of Italian gorehounds. A movie over two hours long is quite intimidating to me, but I did my best to stick with it.

So the good things: Daniel Craig is absolutely having the time of his life playing private detective Benoit Blanc and every scene with him is a joy to watch. I really enjoyed the twists and turns of the plot, as well as the detection flashbacks, which brought to mind the original Murder on the Orient Express. And it's always great to see Plummer in a movie, as he was, after all the emperor of the galaxy in Starcrash. Yes, that's my cultural callback for this venerated actor.

This movie is a chance for Chris Evans to break out of the superhero mold he's found himself in. And Ana de Armas — who is also in the Eli Roth film Knock Knock — is great as Marta Cabrera, the nurse who finds herself inheriting the estate of the murdered writer who is the patriarch of this family of liars and thieves at the heart of this story.

Hey — there's M. Emmet Walsh, filling in for Ricky Jay who died during production. And Riki Lindhome from Garfunkle and Oates and the remake of The Last House on the Left (and also Under the Silver Lake). Plus, it's cool to see Frank Oz in his first onscreen role since, well, Blues Brothers 2000.

But man — there are so many characters here that have little or no time to shine. Jamie Lee Curtis is basically playing a cameo role and you could say the same thing for Toni Colette, Michael Shannon and Don Johnson.

When we reached the one hour point, my wife asked me, "How much longer does this have?" I told her that we weren't even halfway done yet and she replied, "What else do they have to tell us?"

I liked the film more than her. Despite reading reviews filled with hyperbole saying things about how this movie has reinvented the murder mystery and turned it on its head, I thought it was a pleasant enough diversion. It's not going to replace Agatha Christie movies for me, but for an audience that has probably never seen the films like Sleuth and Gosford Park that Johnson is inspired by, it's certainly a revelation for them.

Your mileage, as I always say, may vary.

Rian Johnson writes and directs this wickedly pointy ensemble murder mystery, which finds a large, snobby family at odds over the untimely demise of their allegedly-beloved patriarch and the impending redistribution of his wealth.

The first hour is a particularly brilliant bit of deceptive filmmaking, shifting from one unreliably-narrated flashback to the next, while the audience is left to make sense of all the lies and half-truths. Eccentric to the last, each member of this extended family has something to hide, a personal scandal or ulterior motive, and that's conveniently left out of their fond memories with the deceased. Though it's burdened with such a heavy cast, none feel extraneous or fade into the woodwork. They're each distinct and memorable, even if a few of the actors take things a bit over the top and flirt with parody. Daniel Craig might be the loudest such example, constantly over-playing his best Foghorn Leghorn accent, but he's got plenty of competition. Like a high-expense party game, most everybody has a gimmick. Some just work it a bit harder than the others.

When it's on-point, Knives Out delights in toying with perception and reality, sharing the same events from multiple, highly biased, perspectives. It falters on the home stretch, though, dropping the cloak and dagger in favor of a rather blunt, linear final act. That's disappointing, but not crippling. Even with the limp climax, this is a quirky, amusing, well-composed mystery. Just seemed like it was on the fast-track to something more.

This is a really good movie. I don't really think anyone can truly dislike it. Rian Johnson  
crafts an excellent movie that is part meta, part serious. It has a lot of clever twists and red herrings. The cast is one of the best of the year, with Ana de Armas with a great performance. But the real standout of the cast is Daniel Craig. His performance is funny and has some real great moments. His accent is very good, especially since he's British. Chris Evans, Michael Shannon, Don Johnson, and Jaime Lee Curtis also do some standout work as the family members. Of course, Christopher Plummer is great as family patriarch Harlan. The plot is very well thought out and plays out at a brisk pace that never feels to fast or slow. It builds momentum very well and the payoff is incredibly satisfying. This is definitely a must see and a great return to form for Rian Johnson.

SPOILER ALERT: This was a good film. However, there were some flaws: (1) the instant that Chris Evans (as Royal) scoots Marta away safely from the house and family in his car, I instantly know that he's the killer; (2) when the detective (played by Daniel Craig) waits for Marta to retrieve something in a building, he sits in the car listening to music, which is totally out-of-character - poorly constructed scene; (3) the first cardinal rule of any murder movie is that a potential murder victim (the housekeeper) not meet the killer in a dark, isolated building and indicate she has evidence that he's the killer--that's asking to be murdered (another badly constructed scene). Other than those flaws, it was a good film: Jamie Lee Curtis, Toni Collette, and the other actors were absolutely flawless.

Also, credit for both the film's cinematography and production design as well. This film even has a great balance of old school/new school mystery film elements. As for the negatives, it's hard to say because I couldn't find a significant flaw as I was watching. I mean there were a couple things that made me tilt my head, but still nothing too significant. Overall, I give this film a solid 9/10.

Perhaps the greatest surprise that KNIVES OUT has to offer is that Ana de Armas is pretty much the lead role despite the plethora of marketing material that barely mentioned her presence whilst the movie's main sociopolitical merit badge was a pro-immigration agenda. I guess you have to sneak stuff like that in when you've got the family Thanksgiving weekend on lockdown for your opening week and still want everybody's conservative uncle to buy a ticket. Seeing as the film centers around a squabbling family populated with disparate political views, there is no arguing over the genius timing of the release. It's just unfortunate that since the movie forsakes the central murder mystery for a character-driven examination of capitalism's corrosive effects on the civic core of America, its commentary doesn't have much conviction to it. Since the promised "murder mystery" is all but solved by the end of the first act, for the rest of the run time you get what director Rian Johnson is best at (for worse or better): Subverting Expectations™.

I would hazard to say that Johnson should stick to this tier of filmmaking after wizzing most of the good faith Disney had with the Star Wars fandom down his leg. This is probably the best network television movie money could buy. Almost the entire cast is recognizable, and they say their lines like they're getting paid to do it. Aside from some edgy content it is mostly family friendly. It has about as substantive a critique of American politics as any given episode of "Saturday Night Live". And it's long enough that Meemaw can get in a nice nap before Captain America gets corn chowdered in the face. For fans of "Murder She Wrote" and "Matlock", I'm sure it's a thrilling two and a half hours because it's a distended episode of one of those series with Daniel Craig as Hercule Poirot by way of Foghorn Leghorn.

Up until now you might have thought that this was negative review of KNIVES OUT. Yet I actually thought that the movie was completely acceptable. In fact, it might be the okayest movie I've seen in literally weeks. I chortled several times because some of the dialogue and plot were clever. And even though it was too long, it wasn't as boring or cheesy as FORD V FERRARI. But let's be real here, KNIVES OUT hardly needs my tepid praise to ensure that everybody and their aptly named son "Ransom" will be at a screening near you. Suffice it to say, you shouldn't count me amongst the many people lobbing wads of gelatinous accolades upon KNIVES OUT.

Unlike the Agatha Christies and such that were its influence, this film gives the viewer all the clues; nothing is hidden. And yet, despite this, we are all left wondering until the end. Best of all, everyone in the film seems to be having a great time and this is felt by the audience. Not many films achieve this.

10/10  Knives Out, the latest venture from Rian Johnson, is a twisty, exciting, and extremely entertaining film. It features wonderfully over-the-top performances from Daniel Craig and Chris Evans, which are balanced out by the emotional subtlety of Ana de Armas and Christopher Plummer, and topped off with a large (and extremely talented) ensemble cast. Rian Johnson's direction and Steve Berlin's cinematography offer healthy amounts of visual style, emphasizing the film's old-school murder mystery roots. Overall, Knives Out is easily one of the most entertaining movies of 2019, and leaves the door open for future stories with the charismatic Benoit Blanc.

That's for sure.

Other than Once Upon a Time in Hollywood, this is my favorite film of the year. Rian Johnson crafted one of the best screenplays I've ever experienced on the big screen. Simply masterful. I thought that I had the direction of the plot figured out multiple times, but then each time everything got turned upside down, in very logical ways. The acting performances were great. Knives Out is a simply fantastic film overall. I am most certainly disappointed that the movie got snubbed for Best Picture and Best Director in particular at this year's Academy Awards, especially when you consider that Joker got nominations in its place. As much as I found Joker entertaining, and Phoenix's performance to be memorable in Todd Phillip's work...it is simply not Academy-worthy as an overall film. Phoenix should get a nod for Actor, but the movie I found to be slightly above average. Knives Out, on the other hand, is most certainly Academy-worthy as an overall work. Here's to hoping that, in the very least, Rian Johnson takes home the award for Best Original Screenplay (the one award it WAS nominated for).

This is a more or less a garden variety whodunit taking place in a gothic like mansion with a cast of "names" that the accountants thought would guarantee box office returns. Well, it worked.  We paid our money and took our chances.  The critics must all have drunk at the Agatha Christie Murder on the Orient Express fountain or were seeking favour, paying off a debt, scared of being out of step, etc.   Daniel Craig with a laughable southern accent set the tone. The rest of the "names"  were more caricatures than characters.  (Yes, yes, Christopher Plummer raises the bar simply by his very presence. )  Others, I.e. Jamie Lee Curtis, left me praying that there would be a comedy somewhere, anywhere, afoot.  Nope.  Suicide, barf, blood, and masturbation.  If you must go, (oh, but it's Plummer!) don't take the kids.  Better yet, wait till it comes out as movie of the week.  No, no, no. 3 stars - mostly because of Plummer.

KNIVES OUT is a wonderful addition to the Cozy mystery canon. It playfully expands on a number of existing tropes, especially in its use of the house as a character within the tale and the subversive way it incorporates the traditional "detective's assistant." The mystery and suspense genre is one that is continually innovating and while KNIVES OUT doesn't reinvent the genre it is a worthy addition to a list of best Cozy Mysteries. 

The film is well shot and has excellent sound design that is used to good effect to reveal clues to the underlying mystery. Johnson's tale also serves as a critique of modern American politics and humorously skewers characters left and right while highlighting a central cleavage in our current political environment.

We are living in a golden age of mystery/suspense and KNIVES OUT is yet another example of how great mystery storytelling is today.

The movie had the perfect plot twist, I didn't expect the movie to be THIS good and I recommend everyone else to watch it, I needed this in my life. PS: the cast were actually like a real family, it's like it's a legit family in the real world.

I'm not sure why this movie is so highly rated. The character development is poor. The plot is predictable, so I don't think it should be considered a mystery movie. The humor apparently rests on the characters' use of foul language, which to me, was neither funny or artful. There are much better "who done it comedies" to be seen without having to wade through a sewer of inane and gratuitous expletives. Don't let the star-studded cast seduce you into wasting your time or money. See something else.
